I’m disappointed in the apparent attempt to disbunk organic. All the information seems accurate and well cited, but I think it was analyzed from a biased perspective. It seems that the point was often missed. I agree that the organic label in supermarkets can be misleading and I’m horrified that the regulatory agencies allow any pesticides to be used in organic crops. I also agree that local, in season food is the way to go, but that food should also be pesticide free and farmed without synthetic fertilizer. That’s what organic is supposed to mean. Yes, regulatory agencies have messed up and the organic label isn’t as helpful, but what organic is supposed to mean is still better. You didn’t discuss what effects pesticides have on the human body, nor pollution that fertilizer runoff can cause. I guess in the end it feels like this video serves to diswade people from caring about how their food is grown when I believe what needs to be encouraged is buying pesticide free food, regardless of how it’s certified.

Interesting video but not the same as my current experience.  I have eaten standard UK supermarket food for most of my life, eventually was diagnosed with severe Ulcerative Colitis. Changed my food to mostly organic and raw Full fat milk, and my UC symptoms vanished. Went back to normal supermarket foods and the UC came back within months! After I went back to organic again my symptoms vanished within weeks!

Packaged food that claims "organic" is not allowed to dump a bunch of preservatives, emulsifiers, dyes and other additives, and cannot use GMO's. My digestion had gotten so bad from eating what I thought was a healthy diet, lots of vegetables, fruits and whole grain, low fat, no sugar, etc. It just felt like nothing was digesting. Food would go in and it felt like it just sat there, and the bloating was awful. So I switched to organic as much as I could. My digestion improved immensely, and bowel movements are now every day, sometimes twice a day. I don't stay hungry all the time, either. It is also about the hormones injected into animals and used in the sprays that promote growth. It is about the genetic modification that has a load of problems. It's about what materials it can use for packaging, and many other things not mentioned in this video. The cost of organic is higher in general, but not always. The taste is fresher, cleaner, and tastes better in general. That is my personal experience.

Organic rotates crops, has less pesticides, has more antioxidants and more of some types of nutrients,  but is not seen as more environmentally friendly because it uses more land. However, while it may use more land, since organic farmers rotate their crops more, they are ensuring the land can be used for years to come. In addition, the organic pesticides are less harmful to animals like bees, which are crucial to our ecosystem. So, while organic local farmer's markets are best, regular organic  is a good second choice for well being of your health and the health of the planet. I like the video but it's final point is that organic and inorganic produce are essentially equal. I just have to disagree!

You missed out concerns about the people working on the farms I think. My understanding is that often organic certification also includes minimum labour standards that are not necessarily law in the country where the food is produced. With bananas for example, buying Fairtrade or organic means the workers don’t have to handle the conventional chemicals that can severely damage their fertility, because the Fairtrade and organic certifications only allow the safer chemicals.

The symptoms that bugs have (neurological damage) when dying of pesticides are also some of the symptoms of dementia and Parkinson's.  In many instances, the bug's nervous system is so disrupted that its motor skills begin to get violently shakey, and the autonomic system that keeps it breathing and other systems alive shut down.   KEEP in mind that washing grapes (or anything) doesn't "completely" help with the use of pesticides.  **  When pesticides are used, they eventually are rained or watered into the soil that the plant ROOTs drink from.  The plant grows from what comes up out of the soil into the roots,  into the plant, and into the food it produces.  ** Think of it this way - - Put a white daisy into the water with green / red / OR blue food color....IN a few days the white daisy has become another color.  Having nothing sprayed on it -- It has pulled up what was in the moisture in the soil - - OR in this case, just from the water.

Eggs from hens that nibble on grass are tastier than those from chickens in a poultry farm. Because a more varied diet gives the chicken more natural flavors, which fall into the eggs. I have no illusions about usefulness, and I consider the measure of ethics controversial. But the taste of chicken broth made from chicken that lived for about three years and ate enough grass is better. And the eggs of such a chicken are tastier. Was this paid for by the herbicide or GMO industry? Everything in this video is false. Conventional farming has ruined our soils and we need healthy soils to provide nutrition for our crops, in order to nourish ourselves. There are plenty of studies available. The study, “Compositional differences in soybeans on the market: glyphosate accumulates in Roundup Ready GM soybeans,” analyzed three groups of soybean samples: genetically modified (GMO) soybeans, non-GMO soybeans grown conventionally (with chemicals), and non-GMO soybeans grown organically. Results showed that the organic soybeans had the healthiest nutritional profile and less saturated fat than the conventional and GMO soybeans.

In addition to being less nutritious, the GMO soybeans also contained significant levels of glyphosate (the herbicide used on Roundup Ready crops) and Aminomethyphosphonicacid (AMPA). AMPA, the chemical compound that glyphosate breaks down to, is even more toxic than glyphosate. While the residue levels are below the EPA’s tolerance levels, they are dramatically higher than levels shown to cause severe harm to beneficial microorganisms that are needed in the digestive tracks of both livestock and humans.

Wouldn't it be possible for the big companies to introduce crop rotation by separating their land in as many parts as the crop types they are going to produce, and planting a different crop in each, swapping it for the next type once it's harvested. So for example the first field starts with potatoes, then grows carrots, then tomatoes etc, while the second starts at carrots, and goes forward with each cycle, the third starts with tomatoes etc. This way they would have produce of all kinds ready for export at the end of each cycle. This would enrich the soil with different nutrients from the different kinds of produce, solving the main problem with monoculture - that the fruits and vegetables are tasteless, because they're putting too many nutrients from one kind of crop in the soil while starving it of nutrients from other sources and kinds of produce.
This idea might seem a little naive, because I don't know the first thing about agriculture, and I'm not factoring a lot of things like the different growth times for the different crops, but I think the base idea can be improved and made to work by experts in the field (pun totally intended). Then we'd have the best of both worlds, no?

I've always been a big fan of this channel and its content, but I must say this video disappointed me.
It doesn't seem like an honest approach and/or thoroughly researched content.

While pesticides may be strictly regulated in the EU, this isn't true for most of the rest of the world.
To state that "pesticides on your vegetables are nothing to lose sleep over" without taking into consideration:
- the numerous studies on pesticide's toxicity on animal and human life;
- the weak legislations in most countries that lead to pesticide abuse and use of highly toxic pesticides;
- the effects in biodiversity and the death of many life forms, including, for instance, insects that play very important roles such as bees;
- the accumulation of these compounds and the effects of the contamination of the soil (eventually making it unable to be used), water (from which it can't be easily removed), plant and animal life;
- the perceivable effects on human health with symptoms such as allergies (to mention only the mildest of them);
- the conflicts of interests of the companies that sell pesticides, the powerful ones of the agrobusinnes and their interests on marketing its use no matter what;
- the social impacts of pesticide dump on field workers, neighbouring communities, etc.
... among many other related factors, is either disonest or within such a low level of research and critical thinking that I didn't expect from this channel.

I hope you guys dive deeper into this subject and make a better video, as scientifically accurate and honest as we expect from you

We do this on our farm in NW NC. We raise chickens, turkeys and hogs from April thru November. Then we totally stop. Why? Because in the winter our pasture is dormant and our poultry and hogs wouldn't have forage! It also gives us a break period, which I believe is the Lord's plan.

We don't bother with the "organic" label. It's not worth it, we just tell our customers to visit the farm if they want to see how we work. We sell only within our state of NC. Pretty simply...

A lot of people think that organic farming doesn't use pesticides or fertilizers. That's not true at all, it uses a lot of both of those things, but it only uses "organic" pesticides and fertilizers. The only criteria for that is that the chemicals have to be naturally occuring, as opposed to synthesized in a lab. Its safety or effect on the environment isn't taken into account, all that matters is that it's "natural". The exact same substance can be organic if it's extracted from some plant, and non-organic if it's synthesized, even if the chemical itself is completely identical.

The entire principle behind the organic movement (and the anti-GMO movement) is the idea that natural things are inherently better than unnatural or manmade things. A huge number of people believe this, but very few actually think about why they believe it, it's just treated as a self-evident fact. In reality there is absolutely no rational basis for having this mindset.

Nutrition content is the result of the quality of the soil. However, there is one aspect the video ignored: size of the product. Organic is generally smaller than non-organic, yet the video argued that both are generally equally nutritious. This, however, is misleading, given the ratios. This was biased and poorly researched. They presented a narrow argument on a few criteria and clearly had an agenda with the title. The staff at this company is suspect: mostly graphic artists, producers, and marketing folks with one researcher and one fact checker. They have one other researcher listed as a "friend", who is an astrophysicist, which has nothing to do with most topics. That they can produce so many of these videos with just 1 researcher and 1 fact checker shows they are doing very thin researcher. To research a controversial topic, a good researcher would spend weeks on it, if not an entire year. Further, they did not provide full citations for anything, including the controversial studies they mentioned. They never mentioned the methodologies used in the studies, who funded them, and what their limitations were. While this was thought provoking -- to an extent -- any true researcher could poke 1000 holes in it. Go to Google Scholar instead and do your own research. These 10 minute animations are more pop than proof.

This seems incorrect.  One of the main reasons crops are genetically modified is to make them "resistant" to spoilage.  Spoilage = rot = being eaten by microorganisms (bacteria, fungus, etc.).  The surest way to do that is to create crops devoid of nutrients.  If bacteria or fungus can not get nutrition from a tomato they are trying to 'eat', then they'll just die off and that tomato will be just fine.  Consider how quickly a regular apple and a wax apple will rot.  Rot is just microorganisms eating something.  That's what the food industry is doing - they are converting something that has nutrients (and will rot quickly) to something that has no nutrients (and will not rot quickly).  My grandparents used to have a garden.  I remember the smell and taste of cucumbers, tomatoes, strawberries, etc. from childhood.  The stuff I buy at the store now LOOKS like the stuff from my childhood, but has a fraction of the taste, smell and flavor.  Food is intentionally modified to be nutrient-deficient, to improve shelf life.  From my personal, anecdotal experience (not a scientific study), this video is bullshit.

Thank you for looking in depth at the differences between organic and conventional produce! I learned a few things!

I did notice a few things that are missing that I think are vital to this conversation:

Every farm uses different methods, so while they may be labeled organic or conventional it is hard to know what fertilizers or pesticides, (if any) are used.

Soil health is a huge factor in the health of the surrounding environment, and this is an area where regenerative farming is far superior to conventional farming. Farms that use no tilling of the soil, or very little tilling, are able to actually increase the organic matter in the soil and thus create a much more healthy ecosystem, while conventional farms tend to till often, degrading the soil health. In that sense, conventional farming is in a losing battle, constantly amending the soil even though the productivity of the soil continues to decline and the surrounding ecosystem is adversely impacted.

There are people who grow organic food without any chemicals but they’ll never become mainstream because 1. it’s hard work to grow food organically without any help from any pesticides, 2. the harvest is low 3. they cost much more 4. they don’t look as appealing as the “perfect” ones we see in regular supermarkets. My country is primarily agricultural and up until 30-40 years ago all the fruits and vegetables were grown 100% organically. When I was little I spent all my summers at my grandpa’s, in the countryside, where he had a huge garden filled with all sorts of fruits and vegetables. They used manure for fertilizer and they never used pesticides. The fruit was always smaller than what I saw back home in the supermarkets, more of them were bruised, imperfect and you could find little critters in some of them (it was rare but not unheard of, because they didn’t use any pesticides whatsoever). They tasted like heaven. I still try to buy most of my groceries from local elderly people who live in the countryside and have their own gardens which are their livelihoods. I haven’t done any studies on it, but common sense tells me that the apple that looks like the ones from my grandpa’s garden and taste great will inevitably be better for my health that the huge, perfectly round, shiny and tasteless apples in the local supermarket.

Additionally, crops are resistant to weather disruptions because of their placement indoors, meaning less crops lost to extreme or unexpected weather occurrences. Because of its limited land usage, vertical farming is less disruptive to the native plants and animals, leading to further conservation of the local flora and fauna.

Yes. As it stands today, when food comes from organic agriculture it doesn't mean much, regulations are pretty lax and conventional practices are still used, many "organic" farms are barely different from conventional and are able to ramp up the prices by just adding a worthless label that governments only created in order to tranquilise the rising amount of people who worry about their negative footprint on the planet.

However, true organic exploitations exist (and are increasing in number), that maximize the use of non-intrusive methods and do come with several benefits over conventional ones:
- Conventional farms impoverish the soil they are planted on, as many of these farms rely on monoculture to save in expenses (specialization is cheaper). Soils are ecosystems of their own, every plant species has different interactions with different kinds of soil and draws different nutrients from it in different amounts (outputs), while giving back different kinds of nutrients (inputs). Just as if a person eats the same food every day, the soil gets weakened by a lack of variety. Plant yields become fewer, so we add fertilizers, which in turn further change the chemistry of the soil. Eventually soils become sterile, and it's happening all over the world. As of now we don't know how to create new soil and soil regeneration takes a while, so we need to take care of it. Taking this on account, organic farms being bigger (which is actually not forcefully the case) but sustainable in the way the soil is treated (crop rotation, fallow, compost use) does not seem like a greater issue.
- Permaculture techniques (agricultural techniques based on the interactions between different species) are characteristic of (true) organic farming, and allow for different crops to be planted inside the same plot of land, reducing the need for pesticides and fertilizers, as some crop species benefit from being close to others. These farms also take advantage of certain hunter-prey relationships between plant parasites and other bugs, fungus, bacteria or other (biological pest control). Other types of mixed agriculture which reduce the need for land use include agroforestry (farming inside forested areas) and aquaponics (parallel crop and fish farming). In a near future, we should be able to create machinery that is able to work this type of farms. (e.g. Milpas are a traditional permaculture style from Mexico that grow maize, beans and squash; farm equipment builders could create a tractor that is able to plant and harvest these three at the same time, if this type of farming became more widespread)
- Organic farming can be done un urban areas, both near and inside the cities (rooftop gardening, vertical farming), while promoting local consumption and raising food awareness in urban areas (people are extremely dissociated from their food and its origin. Also food producers, as essential as they are to our society, are not shown enough recognition). This could not be done with conventional farming because of logistics and the fact conventional farming does utillize larger amounts of phytosanitary products.

In the end, most of the agricultural improvements should guide our production towards less use of space, less use of pesticides, smaller task-flexible tractors (+ drones), small-ecosystem farming and less intrusive fertilizers that are actually biodegradable and have a higher bioavailability. As the video says, we should strive to eat more vegetables and less meat, especially bovine meat (responsible for soybean large monoculture exploitations). We should also eat less processed foods as they contain corn syrup (maize monoculture), palm oil (palm oil monoculture), sugar (sugarcane and sugarbeet monoculture) and other products whose production is responsible for deforestation, social unrest and soil, water and air pollution.

An area of this issue that wasn't discussed is topsoil loss due to aggressive tilling and buildup of salts in soil from chemical fertilizers used in conventional agriculture systems. My understanding is that use of chemical fertilizers, particularly nitrate salts, over a long period of time is detrimental to the microbiome in the soil and has led to the depletion of soils and of soil organisms in areas farmed using conventional systems. The loosening of organic standards has definitely allowed for organic systems to fall into the same problems. Important things about 01:15 not mentioned:
1.The NATURAL PESTICIDES plants produce have evolved for millions of years to combat their 2 biggest natural enemies: INSECTS and LARGE MAMMALS. Guess what we are! Those are specifically (meant to be) toxic to us. I learned this from my ecology professor at university. Synthetic pesticides can be chemically tailored to harm pests more and humans less. That's their whole point, in fact.
2. Synthetic pesticides are sprayed on the surface. You don't actually eat them. You peel them off, wash them off, or both. This is especially true for things like potatoes, where the pesticide-protected leaves are not even the same part of the plant as the underground tubers we eat. This is PRECISELY an advantage that a plant's self-produced toxins DO NOT have. They are in its cells. Bites from insects actually stimulate toxic responses, so it's a feedback loop, too!
3. Also, metabolism: the more material & energy the plant spends on making toxins, the less it invests in growing the delicious nutritious fruit/seed tissue we eat, so it's either a smaller yield, longer growth time (and expense) or both.
4. One promising eco-friendly area are GENETICALLY ENGINEERED BIOPESTICIDES: Basically, you take a big tank of bacteria and have them secrete some peptide (that you invented and gave them DNA to code it), an enzyme that kills one specific pest (or group of pests) and no other, so it doesn't harm innocent creatures (like fish or bees). Also, because it's just a peptide molecule, it biodegrades into perfectly natural and harmless aminoacids, so you can spray this pesticide without worry about the ecosystem.

I think you are making the whole matter seem very black and white.
The problem is that "Organic" and "Conventional" are not 2 definitive ways of farming but rather a spectrum within which you can operate.

There are practices of Conventional farming that are equivalent or even way better for the Environment and peoples health than Organic and there are practices of Organic farming that absolutely beat Conventional.

But what can definitely be said is that on average Organic stands as the winner.

Here are some criterias that the ultimate farm should meet.

Crop rotation: Not growing the same crop year after year on the same piece of land, thereby avoiding
plant diseases and contributing to biological diversity of insects, there among bees and other pollinators human kind would not survive without.

Not plowing the fields: When we plow we release tons of carbon into the atmosphere and we disrupt the life of important microorganisms, bacteria and fungi.

No over fertilizing: One of the main reasons that conventional farming gives more produce is the amount of Nitrogen they put into the soil. Here's the thing though, the more Nitrogen you put into the soil the more is gonna leak. When Nitrogen leaks from the soil it ends up in lakes, rivers and the ocean, leading to severe consequences which I will not dive to deep into at the moment.

Focusing on carbon in the soil: Carbon is what essentially makes soil come alive, it helps the soil store water and nutrients, it increases yields and creates a better environment for bacteria, microorganisms bla bla bla all of that. The future ahead of us will most likely bring more unstable weather circumstances which means fewer days of rainfall but more rain when it finally comes, if the soil then cannot hold water properly.. you get it.

Green manure: This goes hand to hand with crop rotation, it is letting a piece of land "rest" for a season while replenishing stores of Nitrogen and Carbon through (for and example) growing nitrogen fixing plants and then letting the roots rot in the soil (NOT PLOWING).
This might seem like a waste of space but actually, if we are to stop getting our supply fertilizers from mines in marocco and other places (getting shipped all around the world), it is a necesarry sacrifice and with time as carbon stores in the soil increase, production will too naturally.

Using toxins only if necesarry and very hard controls of what's being used.

Now, all of these aspects can be met both within the fields of "Organic" and "Conventional" but if you'd look at where the focus lies withing the 2 practices and who is practicing what the most you'd see that Organic wins.

All of this is just scraping the surface of complexity of the problem with modern agriculture.

I will finish of with a riddle:

If you year after year put nothing but Nitrogen, Phosphorous and Potasium (N-P-K) into the soil and year after year grow vegetables or grains that take up that plus important trace minerals from the soil such as Magnesium, Calcium, Iodine and Zinc etc. what will happen after a certain amount of time? :D

Fertilisers and pesticides run off in to nearby waterways and cause algal blooms which endanger the biodiversity of the ponds, pools, etc. Also pesticides and fertilisers degrade the soil structure and make it uninhabitable for soil organisms, thus depleting the soil. After the land is left to fallow (for just one year), crops are grown again, whether rotated or not, this fallowing does not replete the soil, and certainly with the intensive use of fertilisers, and pesticides, it eventually becomes useless. It gets worse and worse, and farmers produce less and less, and buy land elsewhere, or make it elsewhere, to duplicate their practice, continually producing desserts along their path. There are massive environmental implications considering fertilisers and pesticides, and even organic agriculture
, that which never uses fertilisers nor pesticides. All practices of agriculture expose the soil to the sun, to the wind, to the rain, all without plants above, after harvest, cause desertification which makes the soil uninhabitable for soil organisms, and causes the soil to dry, it becomes a dessert. The soil stores the largest biomass of life, I think, besides the sea. There are more living species in the soil that anywhere on land, and these organisms sustain the life above. Farming practices such as permaculture sustain these organisms, for the practice does not disturb the soil, and aims to support as much biodiversity as possible. And thus the soil organisms in the trillions break down nutrients, converting them through many conversions through many organisms, they eventually feed the plants, and in turn the plants feed the soil, with leaves and the organic matter they produce, that returns to the soil. The greater the diversity of soil organisms the better the soil. Great soils have soil molecules that have high surface areas and high porosity, they bind together to form bundles, and these bundles are not formed with conventional agricultural practice, organic or otherwise. Soil organisms are imperitive to a sustainable soil network that supports the biodiversity above, and the biodiversity below. The better the soil the more efficient. Nutrients are made available in a good soil, via the use of the bacteria, arthropods, nematodes and mycelia. These organisms together break down plant waste, feed off of it, and convert it to food the plants can feed on, all while organism are fed to organisms within the soil, and are as well converted in such away that plants can feed. Mycelium, which are fungi that are spread throughout a living soil, have a ginormous surface area. They have threads that reach further down, and further away than roots of plants. These threads feed the roots with nutrients and water, and in return are fed with sugar. These threads die, as do many root systems, even tree roots. roots die and new. ones and newer ones take their place, and whether dead dying or newly formed, soil organisms are eating them, breaking them down, converting them, for them to be fed back. This is a system that is self sustainable. This is not what happens in agriculture. Agriculture is not self sustaining, and destroys the native biodiversity of this planet, feeds a growing consumer of its industry, it needs depleting, and the population needs to deplete with it to ensure maxium species rescued

However, how much land we need also depends on what we want to eat. Vegetarian, seasonal, local and organic is a good combo because it needs relatively little land and takes relatively good care of biodiversity. There is something better though: If agriculture is not just organic, but regenerative, we can restore soil, take better care of ecosytems and sequester atmospheric carbon all at the same time (!). And let's not forget that buying directly from small farmers is crucial to empowering local communities and economies, shrinking the carbon footprint, protecting rural areas and making societies more equitable. I'm disappointed in (otherwise awesome) kurzgesagt for having made an x vs. y video when agriculture+ecology+climate+diet is such a complex issue where we need to design synergistic practices across scales. So, the advice that benefits us in the short and long term is: vegetarian, seasonal, local, regenerative, small.

I worked on an Organic farm for 6 years and I can say first hand it was MASSIVELY less toxic to the surrounding environment. The only pesticide we ever used was neem oil and it very small quantities on targeted small areas, while surrounding conventional farms would be spraying glyphosate on huge mono crop areas multiple times a year. You cannot over look the affect that has on the immediate and surrounding areas, it creates runoff that affects the creeks and streams as well as every other animal or insect on that land. It causes health issues for the workers who have to work in those fields.
Our compost was from horses and cows within the same area. We used tractors for tilling and occasional compost spreading, everything else was done by hand. Soil wasn't left exposed, we would cover crop in the winter. The impact was not even comparable to conventional practices.
Buy LOCAL and buy organic.

I find most of your video's to be pretty impartial, however in this one I'm missing a few major points:

1. Conventional farming often uses genetically manipulated organisms, or GMO's. We don't have much experience with GMO's yet, they haven't been around that long. But what for example happens with GMO's is that they are made immune to very potent herbicides like glyphosate, so that you can spray your fields as often as you think necessary, killing all plants except the one you intend to stay alive. This is disastrous for surrounding wildlife, especially when sprayed from planes, and creates an effect similar to antibiotic use in livestock, as in that some weeds are starting to get resistant too, leading to an arms race with the environment as big loser. GMO's are also associated with companies like Monsanto, who have so many court cases going against them on so many levels and topics that there must be something very wrong there. Read about it, judge for yourself.

2. The video mentions the use of natural fertilizers instead of artificial ones. Artificial fertilizers are made using mined resources which have to be transported and are finite. Phosphorous, for example, is mined in select locations around the planet, and there's a lively debate about when we will run out, not IF we will run out.

3. Organic farms try to be circular, meaning that for example the livestock on the farm creates the fertilizer that is used on the vegetables. Just as in turn plant matter that's not sold might be used to feed that livestock again. Far less transport costs, plus this is more sustainable.

4. More land use for organic farming is a problem, however if this would be coupled with consuming less meat - which we have to anyway either by choice or later by law - we will actually have excess land. The land argument is only a problem because of our consumption patterns.

5. Lastly, livestock is left out of this picture, which seems like cherry picking to me. Livestock is generally integrated in organic farms like I mentioned before, and the impact on livestock welfare, health and production quality is enormous. Visit a conventional pig farm once in your life, check how the animals are living on top of each other, eating the same industrial sludge every day, without seeing daylight ever, while being pumped full of antibiotics, and you will be thoroughly disgusted. This is a practice that has to stop, because of all parties involved. Buying organic vegetables and fruit more or less automatically supports better livestock holding practices.

Dear kurzgesagt,
generally great and neatly made videos, but thumbs down for this one! Do your research properly! While the health part is absolutely agreeable, you definitely lost out on the environment part. There is an abundance of studies that suggest that organic farming is advantageous to the environment. On average, the GHG emissions are lower than conventional. The most significant point is when it comes to biodiversity. Species diversity and abundance is extremely higher on organically farmed land, there are loads of recent studies from all around the world that found this.
And yes, a lower productivity, i.e. larger land use is given, but with modern organic farming methods it is on average over all crops and land types, only about 20% less than conventional, though of course differing vastly on the specific case. In certain cases it can even boost yields, when you replenish land degraded by industrial farming through organic methods (and at this point let's not forget that about 1/3 (!) of the worlds food production is wasted - goes to the bin in developed nations or decays in developing ones due to lack of proper infrastructure).
As always, yes it's complicated and of course it depends, one needs to be cautious not to compare, well..., apples with pears. Slashing down rainforest to grow water-guzzling avocados in a developing country to serve the local hippster-life-style store is sure not on the plus side for the environment, however much 'organic' they're grown.
The methods and principles of organic farming (though there is no single definition or standards) go far beyond just using natural toxins instead of synthetic ones. Pesticide use is significantly less in organic farming and while in conventional they are kind of a 'standard tool' in organic they are rather a last resort and you go first for regionally adapted plant varieties (and animal races), benefical organisms, natural antagonists and a vast range of other measures.
The main difference is, 'in a nutshell', you don't consider the land just a production substrate to work your standard tools on, but as an agro-ecosystem that needs to be thoroughly understood and worked in compliance with to get it working for you. And that is also why organic farming is not so much about 'more traditional methods' as you say, but understanding the ecosystem within which you farm as a whole. Of course this includes also traditional methods and knowledge, which after all has fed humanity for millenia, but modern organic farming incorporates latest scientific insight, an will surely encompass current developments soon to go broad-range like precision agricultural methods and digitalization (e.g. using satellite imagery, drones etc. to get more information to make use of).
Indeed, it's not as easy as conventional=evil, organic=good, but I must say that it is rather dissapointing that you missed out on the fact that agriculture as we mainly performed it from the mid-twentieth century on (and that is what is called 'conventional agriculture') is one of the main culprits when it comes to global biodiversity loss and substantially contributes to GHG emissions; and on the scientifically based facts that methods used in organic farming have some huge potential in changing that!

An informative video, but a bit far from what the real work on organics is. It gives the impression of a "one size fits all," not taking into consideration the diversity of countries, their economies, and their food regulations. Not to mention the clearly biased choice of studies.

I agree with a lot of what was said, especially that we should eat more veggies/fruits, regardless of their production method. Greens are good for us, and we should make an effort to have them more often into our diets. But I have to bring some different perspectives and studies to show that, in reality, it's a fundamental topic of discussion.

One crucial piece of information that is missing is about carbon sequestration. Yes, organics demand a lot more land for production, but its regenerative nature aids in sequestering the carbon from the atmosphere. According to 2007's report from IPCC, 89% of the technical mitigation potential of carbon comes from soil carbon sequestration. Even though there is no consensus on the exact amounts, what is known is that regenerative organic agriculture holds huge carbon sequestration potential.

Organics can also reduce erosion caused by wind and water as well as by overgrazing at a rate of 10 million ha annually – a crucial precondition for future food security. Also, it's an excellent way to rehabilitate poor soils, restore organic matter content, and bring such soils back into productivity while keeping higher amounts of moisture in it, thus reducing water usage. This specific factor makes it extremely attractive to farmers from developing countries such as mine (Brazil), where highly synthetic fertilizers and pesticides are used in crops indiscriminately due to weak regulations.

Finally, organic agriculture offers many added benefits such as conserving agricultural biodiversity, reducing environmental degradation impacts, and integrates farmers into high-value food chains.

The point of my comments here is that we should be careful at how we approach certain situations, especially when they are directly linked to our health. To cherry-pick studies to make a certain point, while ignoring others that would bring a counterpoint and diversity to viewers, so to let them make their decisions, is wrong, to say the least. It's disappointing to see such a debate be simplified in a way that leads people into thinking that organic regenerative agriculture is just " A way of life," or a "fake trend." Although I agree that there is a lot of scam cases around, which contribute to this "bad fame."

The topic of organic regenerative agriculture deserves much more debate, especially on how we can integrate good practices from both sides so to create better food systems and strive towards food sovereignty.

For those who are interested, there's a LOT of good practices around the globe, and I'm more than happy to share some of them with you + sources.

Very important to not only look at what is said in this video, but what is NOT said. Some strawman arguments are used, cherry-picking the topics where evidence against organic is strongest. I can quote numerous peer-reviewed studies that show organic's far superior performance on environmental impact, livelihood, food sovereignty, farmer income, etc.Also, the ownership of the means of production in the hands of a few large corporations (sadly, also organic in some cases) is not mentioned (I wonder why? Perhaps because this channel might be supported by a few of those?) Organic livestock management vs. conventional is another area not touched, as conventional is clearly much more damaging to the environment, and the animal welfare is much higher in an organic system. But, I have to applaud Kurzgesagt for the channel and the opportunity to debate this topic. The topic of organic vs. non-organic is sadly much more complex than what this video tries to show. Sometimes "kurzgesagt" is not the way to represent both sides adequately :)

As a horticulture student I suggest looking into regeneratively farmed foods rather than just organic. Regenerative goes much farther in ensuring soil and ecological health thus allowing for more nutrient dense and ethically sourced produce. Permaculture practices are typically used to reduce the need for either organic or conventional pesticides. For example: Plant umbelliferous flowers to attract wasps that will eat caterpillars and other pests. Methods like this reduce the need for toxins and ensure biodiversity. Of course this requires knowledge of the farm you're buying from that may be hard to get but if you have the means its very much worth it.

As an Ecologist and someone who grew up eating real organic food as a kid back in my country let me just say.. For anyone who thinks this is a new trend, organic methods have been used for thousands of years and are still used in many countries.
First point, ‘scientists are not sure if antioxidants are actually good for you’- um Antioxidants ARE minerals and nutrients that prevent cell damage and help to bust your immune system, vitamin A, C & E are examples of antioxidants.


Taste difference – not just the taste but the appearance and storage durability of organic real produce is superior. I can also use the seeds (yes they come with seeds unlike synthetic) and regrow them to keep the cycle going thus reducing my own plastic use and carbon footprint. Oh and in crazy times like these organic systems are very useful!

Impact on the environment – yes organic food requires more land and many suppliers and organizations lie about selling organic. But which one is more sustainable? This cannot be answered easily as you have to involve politics. The Free Trade Agreement for example, affects local organic farmers in my home country Colombia, we can grow sustainable organic food for the whole country and could import abroad, because we have the land and the climate but the deal is that we have to import food from Europe, from synthetic methods because they do not have the land and the same resources than us. Whilst the deal is economically beneficial for a few, the local farmers are jobless and have to throw tonnes of food away adding to poverty and green-house gases. And this is the situation in MANY countries around the world! Therefore both methods can be used sustainably depending on where they are used if correct and JUST regulations are put in place. This is also why organic is expensive in some countries and not in others.

Synthetic fertilizer and pesticides effect on soil - soil chemistry is changing due to these products, is becoming less fertile (food less nutritious) and it is losing its drainage capacity increasing erosion which causes flooding. Crops are also losing its natural nitrogen-fixing capacities meaning each time more fertilizers have to be used, this excess of N runs down into our waterways causing a negative impact on wildlife and us if we drink from this.

There are also many other issues with GMOs such as the effect on farmers health and how the big companies bully them into using GMO’s! The die-off of pollinators, the food wastage issue with supermarkets only selling certain looking foods is also related to all of this… monoculture impacts on the environment and many crop species going extinct… overpopulation… this is all related
So when you say ‘Eating veggies is more important for your health than how they were produced’ is telling people to just stay ignorant
Finally. Someone dared to tell the truth! Thanks!

This video has got both good and bad information. Truly organic, crops grown without pesticides or chemical fertilizer is much better for the environment and generally much more nutritious also.

When chemicals are used on the crop it kills the microbiology in the soil. The microbiology actually eats the minerals in the soil, poops them out, thus making them available to the crop. Food conventionally grown year after on the same soil becomes devoid of minerals because there is no more microbiology to produce minerals for the crop, making it much less nutritious.



This video is correct when it says that eating fruits and veggies in season is better. Fresh produce has a higher concentration of enzymes which are key building blocks for building health. But it is also even healthier to eat foods that have fewer toxins and more minerals. As far as taking up more land to grow organically for the same amount of crops as conventional, this is partially true. Many new organic growers do not understand soil fertility which is key to producing high yields from the land. Those who truly understand soil fertility and the organic approach can produce yields of as much or even higher than conventionally grown crops.

There's a serious flaw on this video, which is not often seen in Kurzgesagt.
All of it assumes that there are strict regulations on the use of pesticides & that these regulations are applied de facto. The major problem is happens when 1. due to lobbying, pesticides/herbicides that shouldn't be allowed become allowed; 2. the legislation is good but not strictly followed due to lack of inspection and punishment of those who disobey the law.


This can be very subtle, for example, a) the farmer not following the protocol that requires the wind to be slower than a certain speed when applying the pesticide, and then the pesticides gets out of the crop and reaches nearby fauna & flora; b) the protocol that says the pesticide shouldn't be used if there are groundwater reservoirs that aren't deep enough to be protected (so the water gets contaminated with the pesticide).


These kinds of misuses of pesticides do cause harm for the environment and for humans but they cannot be detected by sampling the final product (i.e the apple). That's why the effects will either show themselves elsewhere OR the effects are known and allowed when they should not (in case of pesticides legalized by lobbying or changes in legislation that often become too soft when certain governments win elections, such as far right parties -- this happened in Brazil, the largest exporter in the world of uncountable crops, in 2019: a far-right president won the elections and pushed for subtle changes that resulted in 63 new pesticides being regularized in less than 1 year, many of which had been disapproved in previous years, and also many of which would not have passed under the previous legislation).

GMO vs Organic doesn't really matter from an environmental standpoint, the real problem is with mono-culturing across the agriculture industry as a whole, both organic and non-organic. The extremely high demand for certain foods all year round (corn, tomatoes, strawberries, you name it) results in both farmers and growing companies to plant massive fields of the same crop over and over and over again.


You see, the way farming used to be more commonly practiced is with a methodology called crop rotation. When you plant something in the ground, be it anything from potatoes to pineapples, they take nutrients from the soil (which gives them their flavor) and leaves nutrients behind when they're harvested (which enriches the soil). This is pretty much how all farming of any kind was done for a majority of our history, because each time a crop is harvested it leaves better and better soil for the next crop to be grown and harvested in.


However... when industrialization took the agriculture industry by storm and year-round demand for certain crops increased, a lot of growers stopped rotating crops all together and focused their entire operations on one crop specifically as opposed to several in a year, which is called mono-culturing. From a business perspective this may seem like it makes sense, as you'd want to grow, sell, and specialize in whatever crop is in highest demand or at highest market price, but what happens from an agriculture perspective is actually counter-intuitive. When you make one field grow the same crop over and over again you're putting too many nutrients from one kind of crop in the soil while starving it of nutrients from other sources or kinds of produce... so gradually, over time, the fertility of the field (which is its ability to grow large yields of crops) diminishes, as does the natural flavors of produce grown in those fields, which often leads to a more bland tasting product. This is why many people complain about GMO produce not being as flavorful as "organic", because GMO crops and monocultures are the predominant choice for corporate growing companies who specialize in one or two products on a massive scale, companies like the Dole Pineapple company for example.

Unfortunately organic labels don't demand much. Ideally they would be no-till, building up soil, reducing the need for fertilizer, increasing yields and creating a noticeable difference in nutrient content in food. Organic would also ideally work with polycultures, avoiding the need for pest control (pests thrive on monoultures because there is always more of their food right there). Polycultures, especially agroforestry systems are more efficient on the land due to greater yields from different crops using up three-dimensional space. Above-ground they take turns photosynthesizing and then shading each other (saving water plus plants don't need more than 8-9 hours of sunlight a day to do their daily photosynthesis, summer days can have 14-17 hours, so growing crops in part shade is viable and gives you extra yields in fruits and nuts). Below-ground, mixing annuals, perennials, shrubs and trees means every depth of the soil is being taken advantage of. Not to mention the carbon trapping this world needs.

Polycultures and soil building take more skill and are more labor intensive, this would make organic cost more, but the reality is we should be spending more on food and less on all the junk we buy and throwaway and replace over and over. Get a 100 dollar phone instead of an iphone and invest in local small-scale organics, trust me.

As far as pesticides not being more toxic than drinking wine, tell that to the field workers, I've worked in strawberry monocultures, apricot orchards, vineyards, its like being in World War 1. People have to wear hazmat suits to apply pesticides/herbicides/fungicides, the air becomes unbreathable and you feel sick and nauseous just being nearby. Workers would be sick on and off all the time. It startles me how little scientists and youtubers analyzing data from afar understand about farming and gardening. Try home-grown produce and compare the taste with what you get at the supermarket and no amount of data will convince you there isn't a difference.

I recommend working with regenerative and syntropic practices, both systems being from SOuth America, where the green revolution destroyed everything and they had to figure out how to grow food on dead land by regenerating it, most English-speakers don't know about them.

The ethical solution:  Grow your own organic food.  Plow up your damn lawn and grow food instead. This video asserts that conventional farming is better for the environment because it consumes less land; it also suggests that distribution of organic food increases CO2 emissions.  Grow your own food and you eliminate the extra CO2 of distribution.  Plow up your environmentally undesirable lawn (replacing it with a vegetable garden) and you eliminate the additional land required by organic farming.  If you have this option, it is the ethical choice.  And you can give your surplus to people who don't have this option.

There is a considerable difference between organic and non-organic. One thing left unmentioned and could be the deciding factor for some, is the health benefits of avoiding GMO ( the fact that Monsanto has been found guilty of producing GMO crops using Glyphosate, a highly carcinogenic toxin specifically found in Round Up, is concerning enough). Here is another contributing factor in choosing organic food: Non-organic/ GMO seeds are forcibly sold to farmers. Most of them are met with threats if they don't comply. Unbeknownst to a lot of people, GMO crops do not produce seeds (ie frankenseeds). This forces farmers to purchase GMO seeds from sellers in order to save their livelihood and as a result, farmers can't harvest and collect their own seeds.  The idea that GMO production produce more crops and in essence could possibly help resolve the food crisis is misleading. In actuality, this only serves the GMO producers' interests. It doesn't support independent farmers, it doesn't promote self sufficiency and in the long term - it's not sustainable.

@kurzgesagt thank you for actually keeping a level head, saying that organic or bio isn't better. I study plant sciences and when we did some calculations we got less emission/kg produce, with less land needed. I don't think bio labels are good, I think the rules for everyone should change. If the right rules are generated, there is no use for the bio label. I live in the netherlands, perhaps the forefront with regards to farming, and I have this note about the most bs rule in bio food: it must be produced on full ground. To someone unspecialized that might sound like it is logical, but for the current state of agriculture it is utter rubbish. There's hydroponic systems using up all the waste that's a side product from fish. You'd think I just mentioned the major reason but that is a sidenote on a small scale. there are currently greenhouses that are carbon neutral (solar energy+heat pumps), yet they are unable to put on any "bio" label even though they were harvested carbon neutrally, without the use of pesticides (most greenhouses don't even get infections, so there is no need for fungicides). As with pests, there is a reason why you can buy ladybugs on amazon, it's used in greenhouses to combat pests.

Using probiotics is your best bet to stay away from most pesticides the issue with conventional farming and mono culture is the amount being sprayed. With GMO crops the problem is expanded. For example Bt crops use a very safe bacterium call Baccilus thuringiensis (spelling may be off on that) that passes through our intestines without activating and they truncate (shortens) the molecule and puts it through out the plant. It has been shown to get past the digestive track into the blood stream and also into fetal tissue of pregnant women where is should not be. Considering it shreds soft bodies insects from the inside when activated you can see the problem.

Please make a new video about this subject, but this time include regenerative agriculture techniques that produce healthy food whilst regenerating damaged ecosystems and eroded soils by using  permaculture design, holistic management and keyline design. It is vital for the health of our planet and our society that we shift to regenerative agriculture, which goes way beyond organic. Right now the way our food is produced causes great damage to the environment and is a major contributer to climate change but it doesn't have to be like this, we can actually  put carbon in the soil, fix broken ecosystems, fix water cycles and fix nutrient cycles in the soil with regenerative agriculture. These systems are also more resilient to droughts and other extremes. Please check out the work of Richard Perkins, Allan Savory, Joel Salatin, Sepp Holzer, Mark Shepard, Paul Stamets, Bill Mollison, David Holmgren, Martin Crawford, Geoff Lawton and Stefan Sobkowiak.

I am in Melbourne Australia where it is mid-autumn and some summer food crops are still being harvested (such as eggplant). I have orange trees organically grown in the backyard with no diseases or pests on the large oranges. It was grown with home made compost, in the ground, and covered with shade cloth after pollination in spring due to the need to protect the young fruit from hot winds and temperatures over summer. In summer I gave them lots of water. Now it's fall and there is a slight tinge of orange on the green oranges. July/August will be time to pick the oranges and wait for another round of lovely orange blossoms.

A big point of buying "organic" food for me is to support small farms and traditional ways of producing. It is oblivious that growing millions of corn crops on itself in regions where corn shouldn't even be able to live is not and will never be the way to go if we want to survive at least 30 years more. People should stop saying that "local" is a trend, it's an actual way to support small farmers that live around you and don't make any profit as opposed to big producers(those being "organic" or not). Those farmers live nearby you and selling their products to adjacents grocery stores (by going through all the processes shown in the video) isn't even enough to be rentable sometimes. Because the company or the store would want to make profit too, they'll buy the crops (and animal products) at extremely low prices and sell them at the low cost you know from you local store. This allows them to make money while selling at affordable. You'd buy from a local farmer for the same price if not a little more, but to them it's a big difference (0,2-0,5 cents to 4 to 5 euros in France) the solution is to produce massively and ruin the land, produce a lot of waste and all that greenhouse effect. Organic can be mass produced. In the video, they are comparing mass production of classic and organic. Small producers obviously have way less impact on climat and they suffer from the mass production as much as our planet. Concerning your health, it's Tru that an organic apple and a  regular apple have little to no differences. When it comes to apple juice or pie... A hand made, home made from you local farmer is way less damaging for you body than a mass produced pie filled with conservatives . Primary products don't have much difference to them as in they don't affect your heath, but overly transformed products yes. This is also a part of the "organic way of leaving". You can buy any primary product and make a dish yourself for it to be healthier. The only good reason to buy organic primarily products would be buying it directly off the farm and home cooking it. Every one can do this and it will only cost you a little more money and time and it will on the long term have a positive effect on your life. Thanks for coming to my Ted Talk!

It’s always funny when radical anti-GMO folk say stuff like, “THEY’VE GOT CHEMICALS AND OUR BODIES WERE NEVER DESIGNED TO EAT THIS STUFF!”

First off, EVERYTHING that’s organic is a chemical. And by organic, I don’t just mean farming. I mean anything that contains carbon. Everything we eat is chemicals. Not to mention, as this video says, even when food DOES have “bad” chemicals on them, they’re not nearly present enough to do any real harm.

And secondly, our bodies were never “designed” to eat anything in specific. Quite the opposite, actually, since we’re omnivores. As long as our body gets the right amounts of nutrients and minerals, it’ll be happy AND healthy. Now, most people don’t get all the stuff they need, but that’s nothing to do with GMO’s. That’s just people eating poorly.

Plus, many GMO’s are specifically altered to produce more nutrients and minerals. People need to understand it’s basically just sped-up selective breeding, which everyone considers “natural” anyways. It’s just done in a lab, and I guess big words and science-y stuff just scares some people.

There are quite some things wrong, dangerously half-true and generally misleading in this. Like for example the idea that it is enough to find one positive aspect and one negative to conclude there is no difference whatsoever.
It is true that the EU regularly tests produce for contamination with pesticides. And the results are quite telling: far more than half of conventional produce is contaminated, almost none of the organic food is. And number one reason why contamination levels of most of the contaminated conventional produce is below the legal limits, is that legal limits are raised, as soon as a significant number of tested samples show results above the limit.
And what conventional farming and the use of chemical fertiliser, herbicides and pesticides does with soil, water and insects (like bees) can‘t just be pushed aside by saying organic needs more area. Besides, I am very surprised to hear that, as it completely contradicts other results, that say conventional farming is the most inefficient method in terms of area needed... (it is obviously the most efficient in financial terms, but as human labour is far more expensive than ground, it pays off to have one guy in a huge machine swiftly running over acres of land... which is obviously not the way to get the most out of every square meter)

What about permaculture? It's very efficient in terms of production for a given area, can be done without any pesticide that would come from a bottle or barrel. It's not done on an industrial scale yet but could very well be the future of farming if we develop it.
Permaculture is using symbiotic and other complementary effects between plants or other living organisms to improve productivity. In it's current state it needs lots of micromanagement from humans. Using permaculture means a given area of permaculture will produce many different plants/foods instead of just one. It's not monoculture but monoculture is making lands sterile in the long term which means they'll need more and more added nutrients which cost energy.

Yall really missed the mark on this one in two major ways.

1. Organic is about sustainability. A sustainable farm is a carbon sink and it is not possible for a sustainable farm to be run while buying ousted fertilizer and seeds.

2. "Conventional farming" is only the convention because a few companies have found a wildly successful business model in tricking farmers into poisoning their own fields so that nothing but the companies seeds will grow. The farmer still needs to feed a family so they do what they have to do and the food is cheap when it hits the grocery store shelves so no one complains.

The real question that should be answered here, if Kurzgesagt ever answered a question without obscuring by oversimplifying, is what happens to all the pesticides in non-organic food. Though whistleblowers have for decades spoke about how damaging these chemicals are to the humans that ingest them, even in the small amounts still present in the food and soil after washing and cleaning, it was only recently proven scientifically that they are in fact poisonous, damaging, and possibly carcinogenic. Whether or not the practice of growing GMO seeds itself is a bad thing is still debated, but I won't go one way or the other on that, because the worst part of using GMO crops is that it lets us get away with dousing crops with glyphosates and other chemicals, which the plants have been modified to be resistant or immune to.

As for the non-issue regarding nutritional value, that would not be affected by whether or not the seeds are GMO or not. Nutritional value comes from the soil the seeds are grown in. However, as many commenters pointed out, growing GMO foods lets us get away with soil depletion, another practice that organic farmers simply can't indulge in because they cannot take those kinds of risks.

The people that eat organic are not following the "latest hot trend that will fall away in a few years", they are people that have done their research. Clearly more than you have, Kurz. And, it isn't going away any time soon.Personally, I will eat GMO food as long as it's not full of glyphosates, no problem there, and I am glad to see conventional farmers picking up organic farming practices like using organic fertilizers with GMO crops - this is fine. When I do eat conventionally grown food, it produces a painful intestinal inflammation each and every time, which organic or non-sprayed GMO food does not. On that alone, my choice was easy, and it led me to do a lot of research to learn why this was happening. Now imagine similar triggers in many ordinary people, individuals and parents choosing to buy organic food for their kids and themselves. Starts to look a lot less like hysteria of the 'vaccines cause autisms!!1' (they don't) stripe and more like a rational response to an insane industry's practices.

whether or not pesticides are harmful to us, mass farming and agriculture has had such a negative effect on the environment. The planet is at the start of a sixth mass extinction in its history, with huge losses already reported in larger animals that are easier to study. But insects are by far the most varied and abundant animals, outweighing humanity by 17 times. They are “essential” for the proper functioning of all ecosystems, the researchers say, as food for other creatures, pollinators and recyclers of nutrients.

Insect population collapses have recently been reported in Germany and Puerto Rico, but the review strongly indicates the crisis is global. The researchers set out their conclusions in unusually forceful terms for a peer-reviewed scientific paper: “The [insect] trends confirm that the sixth major extinction event is profoundly impacting [on] life forms on our planet.

“Unless we change our ways of producing food, insects as a whole will go down the path of extinction in a few decades,” they write. “The repercussions this will have for the planet’s ecosystems are catastrophic to say the least.”
The analysis, published in the journal Biological Conservation, says intensive agriculture is the main driver of the declines, particularly the heavy use of pesticides. Urbanisation and climate change are also significant factors.

Something to note about how much food is grown on a piece of land, Organic vs Conventional: 

The video said that Organic Farming needs more land to produce the same amount of ONE crop as it takes to grow on industrial agriculture farms. That may be true, but that's only because they are talking about ONE crop. And here in lies the issue, Big Ag farms farm monocultures (one crop farms), take corn for example. You may have one farm that has a 1000 acres of corn. Many organic farms that grow naturally, some may even be permaculture farms, grow multiple crops and other foods (like chickens and ducks) on their piece of land. So in fact, they are growing more food than conventional farming on less land, just not more of that one crop. If you want to know more, look up Permaculture farming books or websites. Many of these use natural predators as their pesticides and don't need to spray at all... So, do us all a favor and get rid of the fantasy that Big Agriculture Industrial farming can feed the world, cause it hasn't, it can't, and it won't.

Organic or not - there are many things wrong with conventional farming procedure.
Firstly - Pesticides. Generations of crop harming pests can grow tolerant to the recommended doses of pesticides and within years you'd need more of it to kill them. But when it comes to natural pesticides, to a number of them, pests don't grow resistances the way they grow towards inorganic ones.
Secondly - Chemical Fertilizers. Chemical fertilizers, over time, cause the cohesion between soil particles to weaken. Thus soil fertility will decrease and the soil will become unusable in the long term. Crop rotation and organic manure can counter this problem. And perhaps discarding chemical fertilizers completely is not the best solution either. Perhaps, in a definite dose, chemical fertilizers will only insignificantly reduce soil fertility in the long term.
The truth is, with our climate and environment at stake, we have to find ways to keep feeding our huge population and, at the same time, make sure to not put too much strain on the earth. And techniques that are often used in organic farming procedures like crop rotation, organic fertilizers and natural pesticides are, in fact, more sustainable than our modern conventional ways of farming. But perhaps like it is said at the end of the video - we may have to find a way to combine the best of both worlds - conventional and organic - to keep producing food for the masses without causing the demise of our beloved Mother Earth.

This video leaves out massively important parts of the organic vs conventional debate. For instance, how can you talk about pesticides without the mention of bioaccumulation? While sure, pesticides on a single item of produce are very low. But through consumption over time they accumulate in ourselves, organisms in the local ecosystem, and the farmers that cultivate the produce, leading to oftentimes severe side effects. This is not new knowledge either, Carson's 'Silent Spring' from 1962 investigates this topic HEAVILY. While I agree conventional farming practices are far more pragmatic, I don't think we should come to the conclusion: "we need both" without a more nuanced analysis. Note how this video also fails to conclude whether one is more ethical or than the other. This displays either negligence or bias by its creator(s). Disappointing.

Organic agriculture avoids this through for example agroforestry systems, crop rotation, hybridcultures, organic fertilizers, etc. Soil erosion is a very big problem in agriculture and it is very important to maintain the soil fertility. Otherwise we will get a very big problem, because no food will grow anymore. So a sustainable agriculture might be the less efficient one, but it is the one agriculture, which guarantees, that following generations have soil to farm. I think that's a really important information for the decision between organic and conventional food.

One grows stuff in soil stripped almost to sand, the other requires soil maintenance standards, at least in the US. One encourages cultivation of beneficial insects and secondary flora, one soaks everything in dioxin. One encourages biodiversity, the other is encouraging the reduction of all food species to a handful. One has seed swaps and open-source practices, the other locks farmers into onerous contracts. One embraces mutualism, the other had been caught deliberately contaminating other farms downwind to move in on land. And the study you cite about increased land use conflates non-industrial clear-cut organic production in the global south with modern cultivation standards in the G20, drastically dragging the mean land use up.

However, there is a purity fetish issue in the organic world, and I'm glad you called it out. It's past time consumers and growers in the organic world got more clear-eyed, it's holding the movement back.

organic is good for the planet and what's good for the planet is good for your body in the long run. second thought, despite having a british accent and a cute animation to make people think he's smart, he offers no evidence/insight on why he thinks local is better than organic. he just says "seasonal is the true organic." local vs. organic is a complicated debate and i'd say which is better depends on how far away the organic is made and how close by the local food really is, and also who the local producer is. is it a small, socially beneficial operation like your local co-op or is it a corporate farm that happens to be nearby? just because something is local doesn't negate it's other potential negatives. all massive corporations with horrible eco/business practices are local to someone, somewhere. he just vastly oversimplifies this immensely complex topic to play on people's desire to believe in conspiracy theories. and on top of that, unless you're at whole foods or a Co Op you probably won't have many local options, so organic is often the only ecofriendly choice available to the large majority of consumers, esp. those who are less wealthy.

saying "what you eat is much more important than how it's produced" is the same thing as saying that "the workout you do is more important than the workout clothes you wear." of course it is if your ONLY consideration is the immediate health impact on your own body, but he's essentially saying you should ignore all other consequences of your purchases except how they impact you and only you. what if your workout clothes were made in a sweatshop in Syria by ISIS slaves? and you bought $100 of workout clothes a week like you do with food? this guy would be here saying it's a myth that buying ISIS clothes is bad for you. it's just tremendously misleading and conveniently ignores the larger reality.

To everyone that has a negative stance towards organics: the current problems with organics including the ones mentioned in this video regard people abusing, taking advantage of, and misusing organic agriculture. In other words, there is nothing wrong with organics in themselves, it is the producer's responsibility and blame. There are literally myriads of different agricultural techniques that are more sustainable, eco-friendly, and produce healthy food with no toxics involved; these techniques are just not widely known to the majority and are also less efficient in terms
of stability, and certainty in the expected amount of produce (in other words economically). As for the environment, conventional techniques and practices are by far more harmful than organics on multiple grounds. I will not get into them in detail as it would require a lot more text, but I do urge anyone who is interested to look it up for themselves. Overall, the biggest problem with conventional food systems is that they are not de-centralized, and instead big corporations produce the majority of the food with their unsustainable and unhealthy ways. Corporations which obviously do not care about the consumers health and safety as the food that is produced is bombarded with excessive amounts of toxic chemicals and other substances, just so they can make a few more pennies. No wonder cancer rates etc are on the rise, and especially in places like the US, where many chemicals are legal to use in food production that are illegal in many other parts of the world. As for land use, there are also multiple ways to farm which do not require land/a lot of land such as hydroponics, aeroponics, and mixed crops. Before you decide you have an opinion or knowledge on something, please look into it, especially when it regards something as important as our food. It is dangerous to have a misguided population. That is all. (If you still disagree, you can enjoy feeding yourselves and your children with cancer and harmful chemicals. Just don't blame those who don't want to do the same). :)

Even saying to eat local is problematic. If you look at the amount of emissions produced by one huge trailer truck restocking a supermarket vs. many small-scale vehicles stocking the same amount of food at a local farmers' market, there's no contest. Economy of scale wins hands down. Then if you consider that genetic modification can give plants natural pesticides and drought resistance of other plants, you can create crops that need much less water needs and no pesticides at all. So I agree with the assessment that organic and traditional are not at odds, because they have good and bad aspects that can be synthesized into something better. Organic farming will never achieve the most environmentally careful and efficient results as long as it excludes GMOs, and traditional farming can't achieve the most healthy results unless it excludes chemical pesticides and herbicides. Take the best of both and make something superior out of it.

I wonder why the people use the stupid labels of "organic vs conventional" when in fact it should be "traditional vs industrial".

People who support the industrial farming tend to label it as "conventional", when in fact the term conventional should be used for the traditional methods of farming as used for thousands of years.
The industrial farming has only been used in the last 150 years, there is nothing "conventional" about it.

And indeed the most important aspects for me are that produce should be: local, seasonal, preferably from small farmers (this one is more linked to the social dimension of eating "organic"), and of course preferable to use as little pesticides as possible.
(the non-use of pesticides is not linked only to our own health, but also to not killing so many insects and small animals)

Plus, another important factor is: biodiversity vs monoculture.
The industrial farming focuses on monoculture. This is because it is easier to automate.
At the opposite side of the spectrum is the labour-intensive cultivation of tens of species of different plants in one acre. (as shown in the French movie "Demain" - Tomorrow).

There is a lot of problems with organic production, specifically because there is a huge amount of irrigation water contaminated with chemical fertilizers from the last decades, and even with the use of compost and liquid fertilizers, plants can grow huge because of the residual fertilizer found in underground water sources.

On the other side, for conventional soils and clean water sources, growing modern varieties turns into an impossible task because crop requirements cannot be sustained with the amount of fertilizer applied for organic production, which is approximately 12-10-9 NPK ratio. Modern varieties need a higher NPK volume.

Fun fact: cooper sulfate is a fungicide, which means that it kills beneficial fungi if it falls into the soil. ⚠️

I remember doing a research paper about the subject of organics vs conventional. In the end, neither is considered superior. Both have equal pros and cons and if people prefer to eat organic rather than buying expensive food, you're better off growing it yourself to get the most nutrition. But there's no difference in between so a hybrid of the two would be the best solution.

For example, I live in a town where there's a lot of farming. Entering the city, most lands are being used for crops. Some people would believe that these are locally owned, but several, if not many, are actually conventional and owned by major agriculture companies. However, the companies sell them as organic and conventional. I would know because my mother used to work in the grape vineyards last year and she loaded into trucks of conventional and organic companies. So the conventional $1 grapes sold at the 99 Cents Store is the same as the $3-5 "organic" grapes sold at Trader Joe's.

Buying food from Farmer's Markets are no different as some uses conventional as well as organic methods of growing, but will claim that they're organic.

In the long run, it's better to just eat healthier rather than, how it's grown.

In the UK organic food is far more popular than in the US or Canada.  Basic reasons for this are better value and better flavor.  Value is easy to explain, as anyone can do simple kitchen math.  Weigh the organic chicken after cooking it and the price per cooked pound is equal to or less than the cooked price of the inorganic chicken.  The diff is water and fat.  Add to this a taste comparison, and the inorganic chicken tastes like sand by comparison.  Same with bacon, pork.  You get more to eat and way  less water if you buy organic.  Easy to test, too.  So anti-organic lobby seems to be ideologically driven, while consumers of organic food spend no more, possibly less, and get better tasting food.
