to add to kurzgesagt's video, i'd also like to point out that organic food also has a much higher carbon footprint and requires vastly larger land to produce the same quantity as conventional food, which means that forests have to be cut down, mountains cleared, rivers diverted and and land tilled, this is bad for many reasons but one big reason is something called "monocultures" which makes it difficult for the forests and meadows to continue living as they are being cut off from each other and losing their diversity, at the same time many animals fear monocultured agriculture and forests because they appear unnatural, and so they outright avoid monocultures, which is not such a bad thing for farms until you cut off their access from the north to the south then its a huge issue, at the same time animals avoid monocultured forests for the same reasons and are driven away.

additionally it may not be obvious but organic is actually much cheaper than conventional food despite having a fatter price tag, why? because artificial herbicides and insecticides are not used as much, that doesn't much that they dont use them, they just use different less potent stuff and use a lot more of it, then there are fertilizers, artificial fertilizer is fairly pricey but not expensive, but slurry and manure is much cheaper since its just from your livestock, to make it last for when its needed they store it in massive slurry pits that keep them moist and keep the bacteria happy until its needed, but this causes significant greenhouse emissions, but is crazy cheap compared to pellets, powder, or liquid fertilizer.. so the expense for farmers to grow organic is quite low and the price that they sell them for is quite high.. do you notice the profit margin yet?

I must say Kurzgesagt, this is the first time that I am not convinced by your arguments. Whether organic food is more healthy is still up for debate, but I agree that there is most likely no significant difference. And I also agree that certain organic pesticides are more toxic than conventional, however there is much much less of it in good organic farming. There are huge differences in how organic farming is practiced. Some are basically the same as conventional farming, but just without pesticides, herbicides and artificial fertilizer and rotation of fields (thus larger landuse). Others that are much deeper and have a greater focus on the study of- and cooperation with microbiology and the local ecology, such as regenerative agriculture. Where by the amount of land actually can be reduced in comparison to conventional farming, since soil fertility goes up and thus crop yield increases with 20%. In fact, I have met and heard of more and more conventional farmers that have gone over to organic farming because it is cheaper in practice and they get paid more for their produce. In fact, I've of quite a lot of farmers that want to do so, but can't due to restraints by their contractors.
Also, in the studies that you cite on environmental impact I have, so far, not seen any mentioning of the impact of local ecology. Conventional farming has caused an enormous reduction in biodiversity due to their use of pesticides that basically wipes out most of the insects in their direct environment. Since insects are an extremely important base in the ecology, this basically leads to ecological breakdown. All in all, we've seen a great reduction of insect life here in northern Europe with all subsequent consequences as a result. This has of course also to do with climate change, but conventional agriculture is what helped tipped it over. It is ironic that the greatest biodiversity in Europe nowadays is in urban area's, and not the agricultural area's.
Now when it comes to the carbon footprint, I agree that it is difficult to measure the differences, considering transport and plowing. Plowing is one the biggest causes of CO2 emissions actually, since there is stored four more times CO2 in the upper ground than there is in the atmosphere. Plowing causes this CO2 to be released into the atmosphere, which it otherwise wouldn't have. However if you practice regenerative agriculture, have a no-plow system, and use your livestock for rotational grazing than your farm actually has the potential of being carbon-negative. This will also have minimal run-off into rivers and streams since you stimulate your fields to have a better, more compact root system, thus protecting the top soil from being washed away during rainfall.
I have to agree with your conclusion that no farming is the best for the environment, that is obvious of course. And that you should eat locally and seasonally. I find it rather troubling that we are importing all our foods from across the world, whether it being organic or conventional.
Basically, what I would like to say, is that the issue is far more delicate. I highly doubt the issue of ecological impact can be easily and realistically be summarized in the two studies cited. When it comes to it in the end, I have to choose for organic farming in the current time while keeping the environmental impact in mind. This is due to my own experience with organic vs conventional farming, and the scientists that I've spoken with and read about on the issue. This does not mean that conventional farming has no way of becoming better. Right now, I think conventional farming couldn't get worse than it is, but if they manage to create new technologies that removes the need for heavy machinery (and thus no soil compression), reduce the amount of pesticides and herbicides by administering it at the correct spot, and have full control over the run-off of fertilizers, than I think that would be a major solution. That said, I think the future of conventional farming is indoor farming. That would basically be the 'no-farming is the best' solution and have minimal ecological impact. If we manage to get it running on sustainable energy.

This reminds me of when I was majoring in horticulture (applied botany basically) and had a class where me and a bunch of college students were responsible for a large plot of various vegetables.

This pest, I couldn't remember which other than it was some kind of insect, was ravaging our crops, and had gotten so out of control that the only option at this point was to use some sort of pesticide to contain it's spread. It was up to me to decide which pesticide to use.

One was a conventional pesticide. It was designed to kill this pest and others similar to it.

The other was an organic pesticide. Strangely, it was less effective at killing this one particular pest, yet had a tendency to wind-up in local rivers and streams and harm the fish swimming in them.

I wound up in this position because I wanted to be an organic farmer. However, the reason I wanted to be an organic farmer was to protect our waters and our land. I didn't want to do it for the young professionals in yoga pants.

So I compromised on my ideals and went with the conventional pesticide. It wasn't natural. It was still deadly. But hey, at least I didn't have to worry about a bunch of dead fish.

Video is misleading at best, harmful to health and environment at worst. 2 points to make here. First, conventional produce is treated with pesticides that are typically made from petroleum, which is carcinogenic. Toxicity is not a dichotomy as the video claims: There are degrees of toxicity. This is proven by the different LD50 values of substances. Conventional pesticides are more toxic than organic pesticides. Read Silent Spring by Rachel Carson for an introduction.

Second, conventional produce is more harmful to the environment because of monocropping and use of petro-pesticides. Monocropping is not how nature does things; it disrupts the ecology wherever it goes. Petroleum-based pesticide production obviously supports on- and offshore oil drilling, fracking, and other fossil fuel industries, which are known to contribute to environmental destruction and global warming directly through production and indirectly through human use of fossil fuels. Furthermore, monocropping and conventional pesticide use disrupt ecology and result in devastating collateral damage of flora and fauna. Read Silent Spring for an introduction.

Unfortunately, for as long as organic produce is considered "ethical" by a lot of people, a ton of people will continue to try to justify it as being superior in some way. Even if objectively speaking it is not.

In the USA in particular as well, organic food is also significantly more expensive that regular food in most cases, meaning that buying organic food is largely reserved for those with a lot of disposable income. There is an argument to be made that the price can come down with economies of scale, but I doubt that will have much more of an effect. As it stands, the economic costs of growing food with the organic label simply will always be greater than the alternatives, because the alternative (the usual) methods of growing food were historically chosen specifically because of their efficiency.

That being said, attempting to integrate the positive aspects of organic farming into traditional farming would be a good practice for the future.

A pure organic farming system worldwide would sequester all carbon emissions worldwide and start to reverse global warming. Organic farming is the only sustainable way to keep farming

Its benefits are dramatically overstated. And the US regulatory environment for the word “organic” has been hijacked by agribusinesses to a sense that further dilutes the goals of the original sense of Organic farming popularized by JI Rodale. (The perpetual joke about “organic” in the chemical sense goes away once you realize that the term “organic” was intended to apply to the farmer, not the food.)

It’s a combination of food faddishness and regulatory capture on top of what had been a reasonably sound attempt at avoiding some of the downsides of industrial farming (monoculture risk, loss of flavor and diversity, lack of seasonality, animal cruelty, excess pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers released into the environment, etc.)

"Organic" is a synthetic made-up, unscientific label which has no link to the scientific definition of an "organic" compound. The scientific definition of organic (as in "organic chemistry") is any compound which contains carbon-hydrogen or carbon-carbon bonds. This applies to the overwhelming majority of carbon compounds as well as pretty much everything and anything of biological origin, and many non-biological compounds. (e.g., gasoline consists of organic molecules, ancient biological compounds like crude petroleum, and some amino acids form inorganically). As such, the actual definition of "organic" as it pertains to the food industry is based essentially entirely on arbitrary chemophobia, with the idea that "natural" compounds are somehow better for you than other chemicals. In the US, the definition can also depend on marketingforces influencing the FDA as in the case of an organic-labelled oil additive that is derived from industrial vats of unicellular Schizochytrium mixed with corn syrup.

Contrary to popular belief, in the US, organic does not mean "pesticide free", and organic farmers can use "natural" pesticides, including Bt and copper sulfate. These pesticides are, unsurprisingly, no better than synthetic pesticides, and are frequently worse, having inferior efficacy and in some cases exceeding safe levels on produce due to their persistence, whereas many modern synthetic pesticides are designed to break down rapidly.

I am by no means a biochemist, biologist, or any sort of medical professional but i just had this thought:

Antioxidants, by the name, sounds like a name for compounds that reduce oxidation right? We have iron in our blood. That iron is just plain elemental iron. Iron likes to bond with oxygen by oxydating, or rusting. Since we want oxygen to be delivered by our red blood cells, would it be possible that antioxidants reduce the amount of oxygen that bonds with the iron in our system therefore providing more oxygen to be carried by our RBCs which could prevent hypoxemia or low oxygenation of blood and by extension hypoxia or lack of oxygenated tissue cells?

Furthering that, since one way that we know to increase tissue repair after damage or injury is to induce high oxygenation by using systems like hyperbaric chambers, couldn't it be safe to assume, if my above theory is true, that antioxidants would improve oxygen delivery to damaged cells thereby accelerating tissue repair?

Dear @UCsXVk37bltHxD1rDPwtNM8Q,

While most of your data are correct, they do brush of very important concepts such as the impact and effect of conventional agriculture on the environment.

Yes, organic farming has become yet another agro-business and went very far from its roots, and the conclusion that local and seasonal is key is very true.

However, not all of organic agriculture is the same, as you mentioned but brushed off at the beginning with labels. Moreover, the data on yields per acre that those study found is a much more complex issue and compared monocultures against monocultures. Yet new methods (often coined eco-agrology) which utilized concepts from ecology offer higher yields than either organic or conventional monocultures. However, they do need more human labor. (See UN Reports on food sustainability for data).

This video does brush off many many complex points and simplifies the debate to the point that it loses its substance in my opinion.

I agree that the health value difference between conventional and organic is not particularly notable, but there's more at stake than just healthfulness. So what about genetically Modifying the gene sequence of the crops themselves and selectively breeding them with each other. That way we can reduce the amount of pesticide used  as well as reduce the risk of leaching. As  we could the crops will have more resistance insects, bacteria and other things that may affect the crop yield. This could lead to a so called "evolutionary arms race" with bacteria and fungi as they over the generations slowly get resistance to the plants defences making it more difficult. There is also an argument that it could possibly be more harmful to humans, but I doubt it would be enough. It would also save farm land. As the yield will be the same as un-genetically modified crop that is grown on a larger field. With the increase in population and demand for food I think gm crops are probably better as it also means we are not having to make more farmland to also support cattle. Also with the reference to "golden rice" we could also increase the amount of vitamins and nutrients in the food we eat.  However I do believe there should be very strict regulations around what they can and can not modify.

Here's the thing. I have worked in agriculture, and my two sisters and brother have spent years on various farms in different countries and agricultural mentalities. And the real benefit to organic food in developed countries, is their environmental impact. Pesticides are hugely damaging to ecosystems, especially the been population. Gmo plants, while being more resilient overall, have more genetic similarity between individual organisms. So one virus can wipe out thousands or millions of plants. The orange farms in Florida had this issue. Also organic farming practices encourage greater variation in crops which is better for the soil.

Pesticide and toxin problem is lot wrose in meat. Animal feed is lot less regulated. Also when feed is something like soy or corn which is not natural food for those animals it will affect their health. Same with environment animals are raised in, if it's filthy and crowded it means more antibiotics and medicine is needed. Not to mention in some cases post slaughter processing. Also the environment itself has huge impact on animal's health.
Generally just pesticide levels in meat are multiple times that of crops and you can actually wash away most pesticide with vegetables.

Eating organic meat is actually something that can have impact on health. With non-organic meat you get lot more extra stuff than just pesticide. This video simplifies and glosses over things so much that it's at risk of damaging its viewers' awareness. Organic vs. conventional pesticides/herbicides do have a difference, and especially the ones used for non-organic GMO crops (e.g. Roundup) are dangerous. Conventional fertilizers include e.g. nitrogen and phosphorus that cause eutrophy and groundwater pollution and oxygen depletion in the whole surrounding ecology/waters, which are very difficult to reverse. What organic takes in extra land, it more than makes up for in sustainability and better self-sufficiency.

My problem with conventional farming is it kills the soil. If farms don't use any kind of crop rotation and continuously plow the soil then a hydrophobic plow pan is created which is relatively impermeable meaning water runs off it carrying top soil with it and preventing the oxygenation of the soil. Slowly the land becomes less productive and eventually turns to desert. It happened in the 30's leading to the dust bowl and is now going to happen again. Of course a lot of organic farms do the same things in slightly different ways and end up being just as bad so I guess the take away is never trust anyone for any reason forever. (:

I actually did a report on this three years ago. I'm not sure how up-to-date these topics are or if they've been proven/disproven so take it with a grain of salt (but I do think it would have been important to discuss.)

One topic they didn't speak on that is VERY important when weighing the pros and cons of both is gene run off, that being super weeds/bugs. Basically what this means is when growing genetically modified plants you must use a more intense pesticide to kill unwanted pests; luckily, the genetically modified plant is immune to this. However this generates what are called super weeds (or even bugs) due to gene "run off" (sperm and/or eggs getting some unintended modifications). For example, wheat that produces three times as efficiently requires this stronger pesticide (lets name the pesticide XP-123)so it is genetically modified to withstand XP-123. That modification runs off into plants or even insects and we are left with a weed or bug that is also (unintentionally) modified to withstand XP-123. To get rid of these resistant bugs the farmer usually, and reluctantly has to kill their whole crop (what good is a field of wheat that has bugs and weeds you cant kill?)
Secondly, what if using XP-123 runs off into a water source? It ends up killing various plants and animals inhabiting the body of water (or again creating super weeds/bugs.) A way around having to use XP-123 is to instead use a much higher dose of regular pesticide. The threat here is much more pesticide leads to much more run off of pesticide again potentially contaminating water sources.

The other topic that I found rather important was the idea of how these genetically modified plants are effecting the ground. Some of the seeds are specifically designed and advertised to grow in any conditions be it infertile soil or a very dry region. Well the problem with this is that many of the plants that have been genetically modified have had some damage done to their reproductive systems either intentionally or unintentionally. If I remember correctly Monsanto, one of the largest manufactures of genetically engineered materials, used a lucrative tactic to not only generate repeated customers but force one time users into buying seeds again was to intentionally make sure the seeds were "suicide seeds" so that they caused drastic damage to the ground of which they were planted and died at the season's end.

Again don't quote me but rather correct me. These are just some interesting topics that should definitely be included in a part two if the wonderful people at Kurzgesagt decide to discus.


EDIT: There is further discussion on the topics I talk about on this channel

I don't see an issue of organic VS GMO. It can be matchsticks VS rocks. It doesn't really matter in that way. In the world of business, however, it's about who gets to dominate the markets.

With GMO seeds come patents and no one other than the company holding the patent can use it and sell it.
If I come up with a cheaper way to produce large quantities of a certain product, I can sell a lot for cheap, and my turnover in profits will be great as more people will want to buy what they can afford, regardless of the contents of my product or how it was sourced. In the case of food, it just has to pass all the requirements of still being a food source. It just matters that it is marketed to sound like it is the affordable option and "the science agrees" with it. The science doesn't necessarily have to include people with compromised health or those who may not be able to consume the product. The target market are those who can consume almost anything without being immediately affected by it. It's about quickly making profits from those who are willing to trust what is being sold is okay for consumption now before they change their mind about it later.

Corporate companies have the means to purchase ideas and make them a reality to get to their end result quicker. They can afford the research and the marketing.
The local organic farmers produce on a smaller scale and would need more time to turn a profit. In addition, they will find themselves struggling to compete with the large corporate giants that are pocketing pennies from the vast majority of people that need to feed their families from a tight budget. It's easier to get 1 dollar out of a million people for a serving of some food item than 2 dollars out of 500k people. The science plays no role here other than it is what the corporate giant would have it appear to say. Should there be any problem with the product at a later stage, they would already have made all the money to "improve it" with "the latest science". Their weapon is to promote value for your money, and the science and marketing strategies are to influence public perception of the product they want to sell to them. It's like when ads for painkillers used to have a doctor in uniform give his approval of a certain brand of painkillers because he uses it himself. The GMO product with the science badge of approval is not any different. People in lab coats say it's okay so it must be okay. They don't realize that new science is not time tested or sufficiently reviewed science, and not all scientists agree on some things. The general public doesn't spend time researching old and current science journals to compare findings and if a few people do make an attempt to look into the science, they struggle to extract the point of the studies and draw incorrect conclusions. If GMO seed patents are involved, not all research info would be disclosed to the public. That's a win for large corporates.

Nothing makes the selling of products more exciting for this generation than well designed science based content that is promoted through social media. If it's done professionally and attractively, many will easily be influenced and they will not think twice to share it on other platforms.
A lot of products are sold using this approach and quite a few people have made loads of money over a short period of time until their "science" no longer panned out as people came to realize they were being duped.

Organic and conventional being equal... Bull Crap! I switched to organic after being sick of feeling sick after eating conventionally grown food. Before watching: I feel that organic food is generally more reliably healthy (when not toxic and eaten properly) since it's almost guaranteed our bodies are adjusted to digesting and utilising them. I do not think there is any inherent problem with GM food, but there is a risk when you change too much without proper testing and may end up with less healthy food.
After: Yeah, so there's not much difference overall. If I'm going to worry about how my food is produced, I'd rather know about sustainability and environmental impact than if my food has a small amount of insecticide that I won't even notice on it.

I can clearly TASTE the difference between supermarket bought produce and local market bought. I agree the fight shouldn't be between two sides but about the specifics of the production process and the regulation. People should be better informed about the agricultural and industrial sectors do in their production processes.

First things first, I really like this video, its organization and how well it is put together.

But I really would've liked to hear more about how conventional foods are cheaper for their consumers. For example, GMO rice would take less water, less space and could be shipped easily to countries in need, but organic would take lots of water, more farmland and would cost the people in disadvantaged countries an unrealistic price for them. This is often a big selling point of GMO.

However, it is important to address the possible environmental monocultures that could emerge from cheap, profitable farming. Yes, organic farming does take more space for the amount of crop, but huge sections of land devoted to a single crop where very little land wildlife could survive could be a somewhat likely future result of cheap GMO farming. The cheaper to produce, the more of it there will be. My guess is that laws constraining the amount of land devoted to one crop someone can have will be passed (or have already been passed, I haven't looked into this that much) and it seems that GMO will continue to be a better option.

Other than those two things, I really liked the video. Good job!

I don’t think most people have any idea of the complexity of modern agricultural production. Kurzgesagt has done a good job of highlighting the pros and cons of theses two systems in this video and the previous video on gmos. However, it fails to mention the impact both systems have on soil ecosystems at a microbial level. This is often overlooked and probably one of the most important issues facing modern agriculture. Practices from both systems can lead to long term degradation of soil stability and biology. Tillage and nitrogen over fertilization can break down sequestered carbon leading to CO2 release on a massive scale.
There is a third system that is gaining steam. Coined regenerative ag, it focuses on building healthy soil biology by using practices such as diverse crop rotations, minimum tillage, and feeding microbes using cover crops. This improves soil quality, productivity, sustainability, and ultimately food quality. This should be our focus as a society. As a “conventional” farmer myself is my goal to transition to this system over the next five years.

Organic vs non-organic isn't necessarily the issue, like this video sort of states, but it depends on where you are located in the world... Glyphosate (found in Round-Up, a Monsanto product) is the real problem. Unfortunately it is usually found in most non-organic produce in the USA, and it has been commonly linked to some form of cancers. But in most EU countries they have banned the use of it. I'm not saying buying everything organic is the best thing to do, but I think it's important to buy organic for the fruits and vegetables that are more susceptible to absorbing more of the glyphosate into itself.

This presentation strawmans the concept of organics by not better distinguishing the ideal from the reality. This Organic VS Conventional dichotomy is a symptom of the same kind of limited thinking that prevents people from transiniding labels altogether, and seeking out more ideal solutions. I perfectly agree with the premise that mainline organic food production is vulnerable to corruption and exploitation, and that much of the organic food on the market isn't any better than the conventional fare, but instead of throwing up your hands in defeat and become resigned to eat the fruits from the poisonous tree, I would like to suggest that there are alternatives.

I also am very dismissive of the whole fruits and veg pushing tone, and am weary of the denial that pesticide residues are nothing to worry about?

I advocate going beyond organic, and personally follow a raw meat based diet consisting primarily of pasture raised animals I butcher myself. The video doent touch the issue regarding how both organic and conventional meat production is horrendous, and regulations do not insure safety. Instead the impression is given that all meat is bad and you are better off eating vegetables and fruits.

When in reality if the source of meat is pure from healthy animals that are not contaminated by either conventional or organic toxins, then there is nothing wrong with going on a beyond organic meat based diet, which may also include non treated local produce and wild harvested plant foods, while excluding all the other garbage being sold, regardless of the label.

I've come to an understanding that buying locally and not from a centralised shop/store is actually worse overall for the environment.  Each person would have to travel further for everything they need if they bought locally exclusively as they would need to go to multiple local sources.  A shopping centre on the other hand gets all their goods delivered in a far more efficient manner to reduce costs and therefore, customers would only need a single trip to get all their needs covered that way.  Like everything, there are hidden problems that people miss when not looking at the bigger picture.

One thing that is often missed on this (and was here) is sustainability in terms of loss of topsoil. I liked everything else, but this miss is actually a really big deal. Look up the stanford university study on loss of topsoil epidemic. And it's not even organic vs conventional as it is mulched vs non mulched. It just happens that conventional tends to have more bare soil than organic producers. This impact is so extremely important to get across. We have potentially only 55 years of topsoil remaining. Organic or conventional... we need to focus instead on Mulched vs non mulched. The last thing that always erks me... why is the comparison always organic pesticide using practices? There are beyond organic practices like permaculutre based regenerative agriculture, silvopasture livestock, etc. These beyond organic practices are what we need to do more of.

I think the arguments in this video could be rephrased as "Is Organic better for YOU", from a purely personal health standpoint. Non-organic vegetables are indeed better than no vegetables at all. But I felt like it missed a lot of important points about the potentialy long lasting effects of industrial farming like water pollution by pesticides, the effects on wildlife and insects specifically, the business practices around pesticides and gmos etc ...
The biggest problem is we're dramatically lacking serious and independent studies on those subjects, so making any kind of definite statement on the subject seems premature.

I remember the good ol´ days where everyone farmed organically here in my hometown... and i remember it because my uncles won´t shut up about how hard life was in their youth, is easy to see organic as the best alternative when you live in a country that can rely on imports and mass production but the amount of land required is ridiculously high, if all the production became organic right now the ecosystem would be devastated because we would need like five times the amount of land we use today, organic only works when you have plenty of support technology and can afford to lose one or two crops every year to the diseases, basically it works for the consumers but not for the low end farmers

Yeah, sure, you can claim organic to be the most moral method, but if you are at risk of losing your harvest because of a plague then being moral gets a backseat to the need to make a profit to survive

Plus, organic food really just changes industrial fertilizers and pesticides for "organic" ones which are no different in their effects, i mean, organic pesticides and fertilizers can claim to be less aggressive than industrial ones but because they are less aggressive you end up needing a higher amount which leaves us back in square one

The real fault of industrial food is the over exploitation of land but that is tied to consumerism so organic food would have the same problem if it ever become the mainstream method... at which point im sure there would be another more "natural" alternative

And lets not forget another problem of consumerism: the need for top product, have you noticed how all the organic foods look so nice and flawless? well, that is no natural as insects will naturally take a bite from your crops, the solution is to choose only the best looking ones and sell them while the ugly ones are thrown away or sold as second class goods, which increases the need for more land, so, you could decrease the need for land by simply consuming "second rate" food but organics are sold as an upper tier item

Also, why is crop rotation under organic foods? is a very known technique that everybody can use, is like saying that using river water is an "organic technique"

You know what we really need? more GMOs, they are resistant to all kinds of diseases and plagues so they require less pesticide and fertilizers, plus, we could combine some inedible plants into edible ones to be able to use deserted lands as production places, but those hippies keep shutting down every initiative to produce them so this leaves us with only Monsanto in the market, this is also a good example of how the zealously for "green" stuff leaves us with no new actual solutions and just a green flag for the high horses while the corporations grow by riding the trend

People will not stop breeding or consuming so the only real solution is more technology that allow us to produce more with less space, and in this sense organic foods are a total failure, actually, cloned meat would be the great breakthrough we truly need

Making purchases is never a moral choice, I really don't appreciate Kurzgesagt playing along with the framing pushed by 'organic' farms and other 'ethical' businesses. Money is inherently bereft of morality, it's not a personal choice it's an impersonal economic one. You buy the product, not some vague philosophy behind it.

Just like the littering campaigns that shifted the blame for excess garbage from the companies producing the trash to the consumers buying it, and the campaigns against 'jaywalking' by the automobile industry before that. America has a long history of companies shifting blame onto consumers. They're saying, 'If our farming practices are polluting too much it's because YOU'RE not buying the non-polluting stuff.' When the reality is that all food should be regulated to be safe for humans and the environment. What consumers do is irrelevant because the food has already been produced and costs paid whether they buy it or not. All consumers determine is how much money the company has to grow. The 'market' doesn't regulate goods, it exclusively regulates company growth. The goods need to be subject to external monitoring by regulatory agencies. There is not a reasonable alternative.

Even after watching this video, honestly, I’d rather live in Japan where things are more organic with less pesticides, unnatural preservatives, and other chemicals. Eggs and vegetables last a few days instead of a few weeks, people are more likely to buy groceries every few days instead of once a week, and people support local (and this is the key word: local) organic production of food because they know where it’s coming from (which is something I wish you mentioned in this video). A lot of places in SEA too have local organic markets on streets where you talk to farmers and buy from them for YEARS, so you know who you’re buying it from and what goes into your food.

Every one of us has gone to a supermarket or store where there’s an organic vs conventional item right next to each other. You’re def going to see a difference between an organic vs conventional apple. Or maybe you’ve gone to your friend’s house and they have an apple tree — there’s a big difference.

All I’m trying to say is: I get this video and good points were made, people should def not buy into “facts” that aren’t correct, there are many kinds of organic according to their obscure labels, etc. People should just do their own research, but be aware of studies that are funded by opposing parties (yes, it happens).

Suggesting that conventional agriculture is possibly better for the environment because they won 2/3 of your categories rather than 1/3 is harmful. It's encouraging that you mention ecotoxicity, but this is far and away the most important difference between organic vs conventional. Why do you think we had algal blooms in the Gulf/Florida? Rising temperatures, but also poorly managed runoff of nitrogenous fertilizers. This impacts your drinking water, and freshwater biotic communities. The most widely used insecticide by US organic farmers are pyrethroids, which biodegrade in sunlight. They also have to manage their land in a host of ways that prevent things like soil erosion, and runoff. This is why organic certification in the US is hard to obtain and maintain. It's not just what they use, but how they manage their resources and  waste. Conventional ag doesn't do nearly as much to manage these elements. And what about pesticide drift from conventional ag? The impact on invertebrate pollinator populations is likely significant if not profound. The feel good tone of this video does a very good job of glossing over highly deleterious impacts of conventional ag to our environment.

The biggest issue being mineral phosphorus. In non-organic farming, phosphorus is being mined and used for the artificial fertilizer. Which is important for single crop fields and the fertilizers. But it is a hugely limited resource, that is already close to running out world wide. While organic farming sort of gets around this with crop rotation and the use of organic fertilizer, which helps recycle the phosphorous instead of using too much which will run into the water supply and as a result, oceans.

Something that wasn't covered very much in the video (albeit mentioned) is the GMO vs Non-GMO argument. GMO crop produce better yields (less land and fuel for the same amount of produce), are more resistant to pests (and therefore less pesticides need to be used), and can grow in harsher conditions. Round-Up Ready seed isn't all that bad, as Round-Up isn't harmful to humans whatsoever (pretty sure you can even drink the stuff). They can even (and probably have) engineer crops that are more nutritious. Organic farmers also can't control whether pollen from a GMO farmer drifts into their field, rendering the "Non-GMO" label useless anyway.

People are afraid of change. I've seen people that are so misinformed that they think that just genetically modifying something gives you cancer if you eat it. Once you actually do some research you discover that GMO science is one of the best things to happen to us.

Summing up... it is a scam: it is not good for the environment due to massive agriculte land needs, and there are no significant benefits compared to conventional foods.
Seasonal might indeed be the way to go, depending on amount of energy needed to produce (a lot of farming can be very efficiently (high yield!) done indoors with heated lamps etc.).

With increasing population and climate change, there is going to be more and more pressures on proper land use. Here is were organic methods are irresponsible. We need to put money in creating modified crops that are more water and land efficient.  However, one thing conventional farming methods needs to get serious about: reducing the use of high phosphorous fertilizers. This is especially true in the Great Lakes region. States and even the federal governments of US and Canada need to create incentives for farmers in those regions to reduce high phosphorous fertilizers. If you think this is government overreach to regulate how farmers should farm, just ask the city of Toledo what happens to their drinking water when algae blooms get out of control.

This is pissing me off.. There is information missing in this video.. Its a FACT that inorganic growing methods, kills of the symbiotic relationships that are located in the soil.. there is fungi which lives in symbiosis with the plant roots, where the fungi gives the plant nutrients from the soil, while the plant gives the fungi sugars.. This bond means that whenever another species of fungi (which is parasitic on trees) - tries to get into the tree and kill it, the "good fungi" protects the tree.. Its a natural way for the tree to be protected against threats.. Soil is FILLED with life, which plants are evolved to grow between.. When we start to mess with the natural system, we are killing off the soil food web.. This leads to problems in the long run.. There is no real difference between chemical and organic nutrients in terms of the molecular structure.. The difference is that in nature, the soil food web, slowly decomposes organic matter, giving the plants a steady and balanced stream of nutrients (and acturally the plant and fungi and bacteria and such, "communicates" kinda.. Like, if the plant is under stress, it releases Acetylsalicylic acid, this has an effect on the fungi, which makes it speed up the metabolism of certain nutrients that the plant needs, to combat the problem its facing [This is just an example of how these systems work]), where, if you use inorganic nutrients, you are basically adding all the nutrients at once.. this disrupts the soil food web, destroying it, it can burn your plant leaves (nutrient burn), and soo much more.. Also.. If you have a potted plant, that you have grown with inorganic nutrients.. try to take out the soil/rootball from the pot, and look at it.. healthy organic soil is rich, dark, often with a destinct smell.. Dead soil is crumbly, cant hold water, and so forth..

Basically.. Grow organic, and throw a banana peel on the ground every now and then, or other organic material (just like in nature, when fruits and leaves drop on the ground, and is slowly broken down..


OR Grow inorganically, and have yourself a junkie plant, where you constantly have to make sure that you are giving it the right nutrients and shit.. I choose organic.

Greetings from North France, in my family we only eat season-vegetables, it's means half a year we only eat potatos, beetroots, cabbages, endives, leeks, onions, for the fruits we make jam and dry fruits like nuts and chestnuts. It's also possible to keep in life carrots and others vegetables in the cellar. The best meal is the soup cooked with a chicken or a turkey, it takes 4 hours to cook but it's enaugh for 4 days, the proteins of the meat are added in the soup. Eggs are also a good help for omelettes, we keep the cheese for the breakfast and wine for the diner. So our cold months are the best to eat a lot, summer just add strawberries, corn, plums, cherries, laituces, and apples. We have bread all the year. Living like that isn't a problem, imo food wouldn't taste that good if we could it everything everyday. For exemple cherries are only available for 1 week, truly the best part of the year so far, it tastes better when you gather the cherries on the tree. Also when the fruit is destroyed by bugs you can still cook it, add sugar and make delicious compote.

I almost exclusively eat fresh produce, and often pick organic mostly because of habit, but also because slightly processed foods like canned tomatoes and cooked beans etc. are often much better quality in organic versions. But such a system will probably be expensive to enforce, and local seasonal produce is a start.

How food is produced can make a very big difference to the environment... just not whether it is organic / non-organic. Permaculture and soil renewal techniques, as well as agrisylvestry, are making noticeable advances nowadays because they apparently allow large savings and improved productivity while healing the soil. Synergistic combinations of cattle farming + plant farming also make good rational sense, AFAIK.

I eat mostly organic and have been doing so over 30 years. People just want excuses to take the easy and cheapest way out and Kurzgesagt gives it to them here. For decades, I've been "schooled" by overweight and/or sick people who all have read articles or seen videos like this about how bad or worthless it is to eat organic food. I can only feel sorry for them at this point.

My advice as someone in her mid-50s who weighs the same as she did in high school (105 lbs at 5'7"), still has a 27 inch waist 25 years after the last of her three children was born, and is on zero medications is to use your SIGHT, TASTE, and SMELL to determine what you're going to consume (and also to ignore overweight/sick people who make fun of your diet). You'll find organic usually (but not always) looks, tastes, and smells better. There are some conventionally grown foods I can't eat compared to organic because they taste metallic and leave a weird aftertaste in my mouth--grapes, apples, zucchini, carrots, and bananas come to mind first. Actually, I can't eat conventionally grown apples at all because I've had an allergic reaction to them and have for decades. Do your own experiments and blind taste tests and see what you discover.

Generally (and logically), the thinner the skin, the more the food absorbs while it's growing.

I'm sorry, but you are being a bit disingenuous and cherry-picking your facts here. Organic and traditional farming methods are better for the environment than conventional monoculture industrial farming because of its effect on the landscape and species richness and abundance. Traditional farming methods such as open pasture grazing, crop rotation and organic fertilizers keeps the landscape open and "true" to its pre-human condition (at least in Europe where the Aurochs and other wild grazers kept the landscape from getting overgrown before humans took over). An open landscape (as opposed to an overgrown one) increases species richness in plants. Many flowering plants in Europe are endangered because they benefit from grazing. Grazing removes the highly competitive plants, like Anthriscus sylvestris, from taking over every open space. Not to mention the eutrophication that synthetic fertilizer lead to in lakes. Organic farming highly benefit the environment compared to conventional and you not mentioning this makes you just another opinion-pushing channel that doesn't consider all the facts.

Not really feeling this video was researched for properly...as a plant science student going into organic production, I have to agree with most of this. Organic is no more nutritious than conventional. Duh. And it's definutely true that we use pestisides, but the majority are natrual such as vinegar, mineral and essential oil sprays. Sure some are more toxic, but the majority of choices at our disposal are harmless to humans and I intend to stick to those. It surely beats the toxic runoff of conventional pesticides and fertilizers into our waterways and to say it doesn't is irresponsible on kurzgesagt's part.

Another generalization I noticed was energy and land use. Not every organic operation uses greenhouses or all of the land that you claim. No till techniques and interplanting crops to deter pests from vulnerable crops(instead of vast monocultures of conventional that attract uncontrolled numbers of pests that require the use of pesticides)are lightyears more efficient at saving energy than any conventional operation and are on the rise in popularity. It largely eliminates the need for large diesel machinary. It can be even more efficient if you implement small space techniques and of course, grow seasonal produce, as mentioned.

We aren't all perfect, but the good ones work four times as hard to keep people, the environment and ultimately, the planet, healthy. seems this video ignores truly organic and enviromental aspects to cherry pick the ones that condemn it and mask where conventional is at fault. It is a fact that conventional farms put more toxic runoff into our waterways and onto neighboring land. It is fact that many, many conventional pesticides cause cancer and other serious conditions. In fact, the creators of Round Up, America's most popular conventional pesticide, is in the middle of several legal cases over that subject at this very moment. We shouldn't be giving conventional a free pass here. It's like saying,"ohh marajuana has some negative side effects too, so why not do LSD instead?"

Looking at all the sickness and enviromental destruction drove me and my moral compass to become an Organic Production Major. I accept that the world of commercial organic farming still has problems that need to be addressed, but nothing is going to get better by openly supporting the excessively toxic practices of conventional farming. Period.

Good video but a few too many generalizations for the point of being succinct.

1. "Buy locally grown products." Not always true. Iowa/Nebraskans would not benefit from mass consuming corn, which is already abundant as a food ingredient and animal feed. In animal feed, biomagnification means that contaminants from pesticides which have been proven to be carcinogens by Bayer/Monsanto are concentrated in the meat we eat. For anyone, eating a grain/sugar heavy diet is obviously not healthy by any stretch even if corn is considered a vegetable, it really isn't from a nutrition standpoint. There are elements of truth to buying locally for vegetables in that costs can be kept down and this statement is otherwise true, but it is too broad a generalization nonetheless.

2. "What you eat is more important than how its grown." This one is less true on a fundamental level, as nearly half of foodborne illness is caused by vegetables. Cleanliness matters, for both organic and standard grown vegetables. Some companies have invested hundreds of millions of dollars into patenting washing systems for vegetables because this is such a big issue. Dying from cholera sucks, ask John Snow.

So yes, it's a trendy scam. It's purely "feel good" BS. Should have been obvious from the name. "Organic" has a dry and clear cut definition, and it has nothing to do with using poop to grow your food.
"GMO" is just the natural progress of agriculture. We're just now using the better tool we have, instead of purely relying on random mutations and selection. We wouldn't have agriculture without selection. Instead of being afraid like idiots, we should embrace it and get more research done.
Synthetic fertilizer and pesticide simply need to get much better than they currently are, and for strict regulations (with severe consequences for ignoring them) to be in place to ensure that science and logic decides what's good and what's bad, not feeling and emotions from people that have no idea what they're talking about.
Not saying current agriculture is good. Hell no, it's terrible in many ways. But it's still better than the "organic" scam.
The video tried really really hard to not call it that and to try to stay neutral. Well done for sure.
But the reality is not neutral at all. Call it what it is: bullshit.

The "perfect" agriculture would happen in labs, underground, using extremely well defined and strict method, by robots, using every tool that could make it depend as little as possible on humans (error-prone, sometime evil, lazy etc) and on random "nature" stuff.
This would allow production on a huge scale without taking up so much land area and would ensure excellent food quality.
And then we can try to make cubic apples so they stack up better and are easier to transport.

We waste way too much of everything for stupid reasons like "muh feelings".
Fuck that, we don't have time for your feelings. We need to provide food for 7-8 billions people, and we need to do so without destroying the delicate balance we need on earth to survive.
Once we'll have fusion, have cleaned up the atmosphere and the oceans, have restored the ecosystem we're destroying, eradicated famine and extreme poverty from the world, only then can we start to care about your feelings. The first question I might ask you is how many apples or oranges do you consume a year? Not just the fruit, but also products that use apples and oranges as their main ingredients such as apple pie or orange juice? Well according to the data American consumers consume about 45lbs of apples a year, and at $1.57 and $2.34 respectively for conventional and organic, that amounts to $70.65-$105.3/yr assuming you make all these products yourself(apple juice, apple pie, etc). It takes 5-8 years for the average apple tree to reach full maturity and produce a bountiful harvest (4-5 bushels or up to 200lb of apples per tree), so you could spend $525 over 5 years for apples or spend approximately $250 to care for the apple tree over the same time and get a harvest of 200lbs by yr 5. The beauty is these trees keep producing, given they are in a self-sustainable enviroment, even after the original owner has died...

I guess what I mean to say with this rant is that growing organically at home doesn't have to be difficult nor expensive. Maybe you could start out small with a tomato plant (I did, and got 60lbs off my first harvest) but the point is if everyone did this then the lands used for mass organic farming can be preserved for future generations. Not only that, you are growing your own food which is never bad for the soul. I think conventional farms are absolutely necessary because of the way our society runs, but I don't see why if people have 9 minutes to watch this video, they don't have time to poke a hole in the dirt and drop an apple seed into it.

i feel like you overlooked an important part of this discussion by not mentioning the so called cocktail effect.
there's a severe lack of studies in this field, but preliminary research does suggest that mixtures of environmental exposure to industrial and food additives, significantly below individual harmful thresholds, can still cause hormonal disturbances, primarily through interactions with the estradiol receptors.
while people are largely unable to control which chemicals, and to which degree they are exposed to them in their environment, they are able to control which food they consume, for those that have the means and opportunity, its not an illogical decision to "play it safe", and choose to minimize their intake of food additives (like pesticide residue), in an attempt to minimize their overall exposure.

Another issue only kinda touched on in this video is land use and global trade/development issues. The former is pretty obvious - Conventional agriculture uses less land. This is especially important nowadays because, currently, most of the productive arable land in the world is already being used. The latter is more nuanced. One of my major criticisms against organic farming is that it relies a lot on highly protectionist agricultural regimes in the US and EU. Organic farming isn't as practical in the developing world - firstly because most methods are more adapted for temperate climates/soils, secondly because on the business end of things it's harder for small Senegalese farmers to certify and market their produce and thirdly because, by my understanding, the margins and risks in organic farming tend to be more extreme (which is less of a problem if you are subsidised to hell and back) - there are probably other reasons, it's just been a while since I studied this.

Agriculture is realllllly important for development in the Global South - it tends to be a significantly more important sector in terms of employment and GDP than in the North. It's an area where poorer, tropical countries ought to have a competitive edge for many crops (cheaper labour costs...etc). Paying a premium for organic food ineffect devalues non-organic, which in-effect de-values food from the global South relative to the North. It seems bizarre that developed countries spend billions on development/food aid whilst at the same time having agricultural regimes that hinder a major sector of the economy in those same countries.

It's true that organic food is definitely less land efficient than conventional food... that being said, if our goal is really to use our land efficiently & reduce our impact, the clear answer is that we should cut back on the meat we eat -- particularly regarding beef.

I'm not vegetarian or anything, & I don't want to be "that guy" -- but the commercial raising of animals (again, particularly cows) takes up something like 80% of our global farming land... then the food we grow simply to feed those animals takes up another 20%-30% of the remaining crop land. So if you really want to help the environment, maybe substitute chicken for beef whenever you can... & keep an eye on the horizon for lab grown meat, because that could really help us to solve this problem once & for all.

It's the first time I'm disappointed by one of your videos. I think that for once, you haven't worked enough on your subject. Here you're only comparing industrial organic farming vs conventional farming.
There are many different practices grouped under the label "organic farming" and you only mentioned the worst practices (spanish tomatoes for example). The best practices involve drastic changes in energy consumption, pesticides usage (organic or not), food quality, environmental impact (footprint) and all this without using more land.

Probably the best hope for the future is called in french "Semis direct sous couvert végétal" (= direct seeding under a vegetative cover) and involves no plough, no pesticides, no fertilizers, associate several plants and they try to benefit from any possible ecological services
A good example of ecological service : earthworms are better at making the soil oxygenated and mixed than what you can do with ploughing + they fertilize the soil. All this for free.
Conventional farming: 50kg worms/hectare, Direct seeding: 2000kg/hectare ).

So there are a lot of concepts you forgot to talk about and then you skipped all the alternatives that could make organic farming a key pratice for a better future. :(

what you have said about organic food and pesticides is true. For example, in Spain, my father has two huge olive tree plantations wich are considered here as organic, he uses copper sulphate, but as apart of their treatment, as the land where the trees are is really arid and low in minerals, this is a substance that help their defense against the external threats.
He does not use inecticides, he uses traps, another efficient way of keeping them far from the trees.
Still, there was before a really cheap, efficient and really environmentally friendly insecticide which was the product little flies produced in order to ask for help to orher flies, this product was poured in a trap and killed every fly that got in there. The thing is that this product was so easy to get, that "organic" insecticide companies, wanted it out of the market and eventually got away with banning this product from orgnic production in Spain.
So, what I mean is that part of the problem, is ourselves and our lust for money. The ban of this product, made that organic farmers had to move to other more expensive and less environmentally friendly insecticides or to traps, which are made of plastic and is starting to be an enormous problem too.

Thoughts on the use of roundup? This is one of my biggest concerns with traditional production; the thought that many of the "independent" studies utilized for the approval of glyphosate as well as the roundup mix of chemicals are funded by Monsanto, and that there are more and more studies coming out about specific risks with the chemical, specifically to the levels humans are ingesting (up 1,000% in the last two decades) and associated with damaging gut biomes, liver damage/scarring, and potential cancer risks. I have no problem with "non-organic", but we shouldn't really be using much weed-killer chemicals in the first place, as farm robotics can weed manually and at expected future lower cost. The issue then isn't necessarily using trace amounts of chemicals, but rather the overuse of these chemicals to maximize yield rather than quality.

"what you eat is more important than how it's produced." that's how you summed up the video. well i think that would stand as a good motto for the vegan manifesto of wealthy urbanites (whose ideology i too am at odds with). it doesn't matter that the wheat in my bread was grown in a way that erodes kilograms of soil per hectare per year; it matters that i did what the environmentalist infographic told me: eating less meat is the best thing you can do for the environment. explain that to nomadic herders who've seen the soil remain in about the same condition over millenia.

no i think the complete opposite. if what you eat is food, and the way its produced and consumed is healthy - that is, it's adequate for your body (i.e. most unrefined plant/animal products for us omnivores) and it's adequate for the maintenance of a local functioning ecosystem - then whatever it is is hardly important. there are something in the order of 12,000 edible species of plants known. our concentration on just a handful of those plants has coincided with the expontential acceleration of the diminution of wildlife on our planet. if we cared less about which kind of food and accepted an utterly more polycultural way of farming, we would be much better placed to diminish the devestating impact agriculture has on the environment. i think this video is oddly specific (for a kurzgesagt video) and conspicuously ignores much of the complicated on long term impacts of the global food production and distribution system.

i think a better treatment of this subject, easily comprehensible for a regular kurzgesagt viewer would be Michael Pollan's book 'the omnivore's dilemma'.

i think this was my least favourite of your videos kurzgesagt. it seems like you've waded into a field that i have long contemplated and heard so many creative ideas for, whereas your approach was a fundamentally constrained one: we'll have to keep producing food in largely the same way as we have forever (i.e. since synthetic fertilisers came into wide use 75 years ago). i don't care too much about organic; vegan; paleo. i care about how industrialised the food chain is and whether or not the agricultural system can exist within an ecosystem without destroying it long term.

I wouldn't go so far as to call Organic a scam, but it definitely is taking advantage of idiots that see organic and without a second thought think it's somehow better. The simple fact that it requires more land is enough to outweigh the benefits of using less energy, since we can use alternative energy sources, but the more land is needed the more of it is lost for other crops and especially forests.
The only real benefit of organic vs normal is the crop cycling, and conventional farming would benefit from that as well.

Also - people need to stop being ignorant about GMOs. From a technical standpoint, pretty much every strawberry is a GMO. Every mule is a GMO. Every mongrel is a GMO. Genetically Modified Organisms are made by mixing genes of different species to achieve an offspring with certain qualities. In case of a mule, for example, it's done by breeding a male donkey with a female horse. In case of modern, common understanding of GMO it's done by selectively transferring certain genes directly. GMO's are great to increase crop production, reduce the usage of pesticides, reduce the energy requirements, increase nutritional value, and so on.

It's a bummer that the video doesn't properly interface with the economic difference.  I get that it's an inherently political topic, but the fact is that conventional farming methods allow the production of vastly greater quantities of food for vastly fewer resources.  Literal billions of humans in the third world would be imperiled by a broad switch to organic farming because the associated increase in cost and decrease in supply could push them below food subsistence. Further, if conventional farming can make veggies cheaper it can allow less well off people to eat healthier and live longer lives everywhere.  Political activism for organic food is incredibly elitist and morally blind to human suffering.  I know Kurz generally tries to stay above the fray, but I think there's a moral dimension here that often goes undiscussed because it paints some lefties as champagne socialists.

This video acts like ecotoxicity isn’t an enormous issue. That’s kind of the main issue. Companies like DOW and Monsanto have been sued (and lost) for their cancerous chemicals leeching out into the environment. If you grow naturally (I don’t like the term organic because people cheat and murky up the waters) ie. using compost (a recycled material) and yard litter, you aren’t having a negative leeching effect and you are minimizing the methane released when those things are put into landfills. It is a fallacy to assume organic farms take more land to produce, in fact more land is committed to ‘conventional’ (lazy) farming practices to support the agricultural animals industry (another terrible source of pollution and exotoxins). If people buy local from farmers like myself who use older natural methods they can check the farm for unsustainable practices, that is the real solution. Or better yet, grow your own and learn to do it right, then your own land isn’t wasted. There are a plethora or methods to grow an abundance of produce in FAR less space than ‘conventional’ (I hate that word) row farming. Industry farms use tractors, chemical fertilizers (of which over 70% is leeched into aquifers and rivers), overhead wasteful watering methods (because irrigation lines get in the way of tractors), and tilling which has been known to degrade the soil since the 1927 dust bowl. I don’t use any of these methods.

I’m unsubscribing from this channel as protest for this lazy oversight of genuinely important issues. I guess it’s true, you really don’t know what you don’t know, so get outside and start growing yourself.

The thing is that those ecological benefit aren't inherent to organic and could be incorporated easily into traditional agriculture, it just so happens that organic farmers tend to care more about it.

My brother is a geologist studying minerals and runoff around rivers and my parents both work in agricultural management with 60+ years of experience combined. They all agree that runoff is the most harmful affect of conventional farming. Conventional farming uses fertilizers more often and in high concentrations. Non organic fertilizer is cheaper and they also tend to use less sustainable farming practices (although these aren't nessecarily organic) like crop rotation. Runoff can be a huge issue and can spike algae levels and offset delicate ecosystems. While these issues can be resolved without resorting to organic farming, it's still an important thing to be addressed.

The production, or more precisely, the actual growing of fruits and veggies also play a role in this debate, from an ecological point of view. Organic production sometimes forbid monoculture. Monoculture is basically growing one type of food, and inhibiting growth of all other types of food, in a very large area. Organic production allows for foods to "grow together". This is good for supporting interplay between other ecosystems, for example: with bees. And we have all heard how important bees are. On the other hand this kind of production may make it harder for farmers to keep the food uninfected and clean.

FYI I'm not remotely a scientiest, but I think this is worth bringing up

Organic: lower yields, higher prices, you're paying for the label just like you would for crappy brand name clothes.
Conventional: it's been doing just fine since we stopped being hunter/gatherers. Better, in fact, as science advances.
Organic: "doesn't use pesticides" is a slogan, not a fact.
Conventional: uses pesticides specifically made to be harmless to human beings, instead of just being harmful.

I would typically favor quality over quantity, but sticking a logo with "Quality!" under it isn't the same thing as a product actually being quality. Organic crap is just a trend. You get to call yourself "organic" by paying the people who invented the "organic" label, just to use the label. It's not like there are Organic Farming Inspectors who worked for an unbiased third-party company.

Discernment.
Conclusion: Buying organic is only more expensive and does not make any real difference.

I believe everyone should use organic products. Of course, the choice is their own. Rachel Carson “Silent Spring”, brings light to the pesticide problem. There is a thing happening called a “Pesticide Treadmill”. With pests, there is always that one bug that survives the pesticide. Therefore, that “super bug” will breed with another that has survived and the pesticide won’t work. So, they have to use much stronger, toxic pesticides. And then the process will keep repeating itself. Y’all should take AP environmental science if you are interested in the well being of the planet and not how to screw it up for the generations ahead.

What about a video on the production methodology of crops. While this looked at organic and conventional, what about looking at producing crops in fields, greenhouses, hydroponics, and vertical farms? You can compare the use of water and energy, evaluate the impact of natural sunlight versus artificial (actually the greatest resource for growing, not fertilizers or water), environmental impacts each one has, cost efficiency, and what it means to the consumer.

The reason for this request, for me, primarily comes from the idea of vertical farming. While I love the idea of less land use and increased local production, they have to recreate the sun. This can be mitigated by using renewable power sources and color specific LED's, it is still a major factor in its effectiveness. Hydroponics I remember being touted as the future of agriculture several years ago, but now I never hear anything about it.

This video is correct if you ignore ethics and logistics around forcing farmers year after year to buy infertile GMO seeds and the scary legal ripples copyrighting them has and factor in the supply chain of the pesticides and GMO factories as well. GMOs generally require more recourses to grow (if modified to be lusher). Still the best solution is to grow things yourself (cause you can't trust anyone these days to do it right) or visit a local farm to insure they meet your standards. Cut out the retail middle man cause you will find that they been raking up the prices artificially to make a profit compared to directly buying from the producer. Ecotoxicity is pretty important considering their are more inorganic farms in general then organics. For anyone curious their is an alternative to pesticides that's non-toixic but if your not a fan of creepy crawly it may not be for you. You want to maintain a population of natural predators of pests (carnivorous insects are easiest to maintain). Keep them around and you turn the negative feedback loop of that evolutionary resistance to pesticides into a negligible factor; prey and predator evolve ultimately getting the prey creature no where. Also for the love of god do not support monocropping or crappily paid farm-hand wages no matter the method.

This isn't a very good summary of your own video. It is as far as health is concerned but not for the environmental aspect. If you buy local produce that is out of season, then chances are it was grown in heated greenhouses which carry a high carbon footprint. So it does matter how it was produced. The video doesn't say much about food distribution but this is also important. Even if you buy local produce that is in season, you may have a greater carbon footprint than if you bought goods transported from very far away if you yourself have to drive to several different shops to buy that local produce. In terms of carbon use, a small increase in the vast number of short trips carried out by millions of consumers outweighs the difference on the supply side between local and long distance haulage using a far smaller number of vehicles.

It's unfortunate that organic food is being seen and marketed as more enviornmentaly friendly because in a way this is the way enviornmentaly friendly food should be marketed. Many people don't have the time or ability to research what food is enviornmentaly friendly or in season or no ability to buy local food. An easily recognisable branding like organic is the only way for many to make educated purchases. We can't expect people to be read up about any given food's eviornmental impact, the leading scientists are only beginning to understand it. For that reason a new branding and tag should be used for labeling what foods have been produced with reasonably low CO2 emmisions. This is already being done but it can be easy to be fraudulent so we'd need a large NGO or state sponsored program to truly check all produce. People want to help the enviornment more than they do. It would mean the world for public reduction of CO2 emmisions to have a simple and reliable way to know what products are good for the enviornment and what aren't.
